name: Arm Circles
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, arms extended straight out to the sides at shoulder height.
Make small, controlled circles forward.
Complete desired reps or time.
Reverse the direction and make small, controlled circles backward.
Complete desired reps or time.
description: A dynamic warm-up for the shoulder joint and surrounding muscles.

name: Large Arm Circles
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, arms extended.
Make large, controlled circles forward, moving through the full range of motion of the shoulder.
Complete desired reps or time.
Reverse the direction and make large, controlled circles backward.
Complete desired reps or time.
description: A dynamic warm-up increasing the range of motion in the shoulder joint.

name: Small Arm Circles
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, arms extended straight out to the sides at shoulder height.
Make small, tight, controlled circles forward.
Focus on movement originating from the shoulder joint.
Complete desired reps or time.
Reverse the direction and make small, controlled circles backward.
Complete desired reps or time.
description: A dynamic warm-up focusing on controlled movement in the shoulder joint.

name: Forward & Backward Leg Swings
instructions: Stand tall next to a wall or support for balance.
Engage your core.
Swing one leg forward in a controlled manner, keeping the knee mostly straight.
Swing the leg backward, again in a controlled manner.
Allow the momentum to build gradually, avoiding jerky movements.
Complete desired reps, then switch legs.
description: A dynamic stretch to warm up the hip flexors and hamstrings.

name: Lateral Leg Swings
instructions: Stand tall facing a wall or support for balance, holding on lightly.
Engage your core.
Swing one leg out to the side in a controlled manner.
Swing the leg back across your body in front of the standing leg.
Keep your torso upright and minimize twisting.
Complete desired reps, then switch legs.
description: A dynamic stretch to warm up the hip abductors and adductors.

name: Walking Knee Hugs
instructions: Start standing tall.
Take a step forward with your right foot.
Lift your left knee towards your chest.
Grasp your left shin or knee with both hands and gently pull it closer to your chest.
Hold briefly, feeling a stretch in the left glute and hip.
Release, step forward with your left foot, and repeat by hugging the right knee.
Continue alternating legs as you walk forward.
description: A dynamic stretch involving walking while pulling the knee to the chest, targeting glutes and hip mobility.

name: Walking Quad Stretch
instructions: Start standing tall.
Take a step forward with your right foot.
Bend your left knee and bring your left heel towards your glutes.
Reach back with your left hand (or both hands for balance) and grab your left ankle or foot.
Gently pull the heel closer to your glute, feeling a stretch in the front of your left thigh.
Keep your knees close together and avoid arching your back.
Hold briefly, release, step forward with your left foot, and repeat with the right leg.
Continue alternating legs as you walk forward.
description: A dynamic stretch for the quadriceps performed while walking.

name: Walking Heel-to-Butt Kicks
instructions: Start standing tall.
Walk forward.
With each step, purposefully kick your heel up towards your glute, bending your knee.
Focus on stretching the front of the thigh (quadriceps).
Keep the movement fluid and controlled.
You can lightly touch your heel with your hand if desired.
Continue alternating legs as you walk.
description: A dynamic warm-up involving bringing the heels towards the glutes while walking to stretch the quads.

name: High Knees
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart.
Engage your core.
Drive one knee up towards your chest as high as possible.
Simultaneously, drive the opposite arm forward.
Quickly switch legs, bringing the other knee up.
Either march in place or perform as a skipping motion, moving forward.
Keep your torso upright.
description: A dynamic warm-up exercise that elevates heart rate and activates hip flexors and legs.

name: Butt Kicks
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart.
Begin marching or jogging lightly in place or moving forward.
With each step, bring your heel up towards your glute, focusing on engaging the hamstring.
Keep your knees pointing downwards.
Pump your arms in rhythm with your legs.
Maintain a quick, light pace.
description: A dynamic warm-up exercise focusing on hamstring activation and light cardiovascular work.

name: Standing Torso Twists
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent.
Engage your core.
Place hands on hips, across chest, or extend arms out to the sides.
Rotate your torso gently from side to side.
Keep your hips relatively stable, allowing the rotation to come from your waist and upper back.
Move in a controlled manner.
description: A dynamic warm-up to increase mobility in the thoracic spine and activate the obliques.

name: Seated Torso Twists
instructions: Sit upright on the floor or a chair with feet flat.
Engage your core and sit tall.
Place hands across chest or behind head.
Gently rotate your torso from side to side.
Focus on twisting through the upper and mid-back.
Keep your hips stable and facing forward.
Move in a controlled manner.
description: A seated variation of torso twists to mobilize the spine and warm up the core.

name: Standing Hip Circles
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, hands on hips.
Keep knees slightly bent.
Slowly rotate your hips in a large circular motion, pushing them forward, to the side, back, and to the other side.
Keep your upper body relatively stable.
Complete desired reps in one direction, then reverse the direction.
Focus on smooth, controlled movement.
description: A mobility exercise to warm up the hip joint and surrounding muscles.

name: Hip CARs
instructions: Stand tall, holding onto a support if needed.
Keep your core braced and spine neutral, minimizing movement elsewhere.
Lift one knee towards your chest.
Slowly open the knee out to the side (abduction).
Internally rotate the hip to bring the foot back.
Extend the hip backward.
Reverse the motion: extend back, externally rotate, bring knee out to side, bring knee forward.
Perform slowly and with control through the entire range of motion.
Switch legs.
description: A controlled exercise to improve hip joint mobility and control through its full range of motion.

name: Ankle Rotations
instructions: Sit or stand, lifting one foot slightly off the ground.
Slowly rotate your ankle in a circular motion clockwise.
Focus on isolating the movement at the ankle joint.
Complete desired reps or time.
Reverse the direction and rotate counter-clockwise.
Repeat with the other ankle.
description: A simple mobility exercise to warm up the ankle joints.

name: Ankle Pumps
instructions: Sit or stand comfortably.
Point your toes downwards as far as possible (plantarflexion).
Hold briefly.
Pull your toes up towards your shin as far as possible (dorsiflexion).
Hold briefly.
Repeat the movement back and forth.
Perform on both ankles, either simultaneously or one at a time.
description: An exercise to improve ankle range of motion by flexing and extending the foot.

name: Wrist Rotations
instructions: Extend your arms forward or hold them comfortably.
Make fists or keep hands open.
Slowly rotate your wrists in a circular motion clockwise.
Focus on isolating the movement at the wrist joint.
Complete desired reps or time.
Reverse the direction and rotate counter-clockwise.
Repeat with both wrists.
description: A simple mobility exercise to warm up the wrist joints.

name: Wrist Flexion/Extension
instructions: Extend one arm forward, palm facing down.
With your other hand, gently bend the extended wrist downwards (flexion), feeling a stretch on top of the forearm.
Hold briefly.
Gently bend the extended wrist upwards (extension), feeling a stretch on the underside of the forearm.
Hold briefly.
Repeat the movement back and forth gently.
Switch arms.
description: A stretch to improve wrist flexibility by moving through flexion and extension.

name: Neck Half-Rolls
instructions: Sit or stand tall with relaxed shoulders.
Gently tilt your chin towards your chest.
Slowly roll your head towards one shoulder, keeping chin tucked.
Pause briefly.
Slowly roll your head back to the center and then towards the other shoulder.
Avoid rolling the head fully backward.
Focus on gentle, slow half-circles.
description: A gentle mobility exercise for the neck, focusing on forward half-circles to avoid compression.

name: Neck Side Bends
instructions: Sit or stand tall with relaxed shoulders, looking straight ahead.
Slowly tilt your head, bringing your right ear towards your right shoulder.
Do not lift your shoulder.
Feel a gentle stretch along the left side of your neck.
Hold briefly.
Return to the center.
Repeat on the left side.
Keep the movement gentle and controlled.
description: A stretch targeting the sides of the neck by tilting the head towards the shoulder.

name: Neck Flexion/Extension
instructions: Sit or stand tall with relaxed shoulders.
Slowly lower your chin towards your chest, feeling a stretch in the back of your neck (flexion).
Hold briefly.
Slowly lift your head and gently tilt it back, looking towards the ceiling (extension).
Avoid compressing the back of the neck excessively.
Hold briefly.
Return to the neutral position and repeat.
description: A mobility exercise moving the neck forward and backward to stretch and warm up.

name: Shoulder Rolls
instructions: Sit or stand tall with arms relaxed at your sides.
Lift your shoulders up towards your ears.
Roll them backward, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
Lower them back down.
Repeat in a smooth, circular motion backward.
Complete desired reps.
Reverse the direction, rolling shoulders forward (up, forward, down).
Complete desired reps.
description: A simple exercise to relieve tension and improve mobility in the shoulders and upper back.

name: Shoulder Dislocates (PVC/Band)
instructions: Stand tall holding a PVC pipe or resistance band with a wide overhand grip.
Keep arms straight but not locked.
Engage your core.
Slowly raise the pipe/band up and over your head.
Continue the arc, bringing the pipe/band behind your back towards your glutes.
Adjust grip width as needed to allow smooth movement without bending elbows.
Reverse the motion, bringing the pipe/band back over your head to the starting position.
Maintain control throughout.
description: A mobility exercise using a pipe or band to improve shoulder range of motion and flexibility.

name: Band Pull-Aparts
instructions: Stand tall holding a resistance band with both hands, palms facing down or up, about shoulder-width apart.
Extend your arms straight out in front of you at chest height.
Keep elbows slightly bent.
Engage your core and pull the band apart by squeezing your shoulder blades together.
Bring your arms out to the sides.
Focus on initiating the movement from your upper back.
Slowly return to the starting position with control.
Repeat.
description: An exercise using a resistance band to strengthen the upper back muscles and improve posture.

name: Banded Face Pulls
instructions: Attach a resistance band to a sturdy anchor point at head height or slightly above.
Grasp the band with both hands, palms facing each other or down.
Step back until there is light tension on the band, arms extended forward.
Pull the band towards your face, aiming the hands towards your ears or temples.
Simultaneously drive your elbows back and externally rotate your shoulders.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement.
Slowly return to the starting position with control.
Repeat.
description: An exercise targeting the rear deltoids and upper back muscles, crucial for shoulder health and posture.

name: Cat-Cow Stretch
instructions: Start on your hands and knees, with hands directly under shoulders and knees directly under hips.
Inhale as you drop your belly towards the floor, arching your back and lifting your head and tailbone towards the ceiling (Cow Pose).
Exhale as you round your spine towards the ceiling, tucking your chin to your chest and tailbone under (Cat Pose).
Flow smoothly between the two poses, coordinating with your breath.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
description: A yoga pose involving flexing and extending the spine to improve mobility and relieve tension.

name: Child's Pose
instructions: Start on your hands and knees.
Spread your knees wide apart while keeping your big toes touching.
Sit your hips back towards your heels.
Fold your torso forward, resting it between or on top of your thighs.
Extend your arms forward, resting your forehead on the floor.
Alternatively, rest arms alongside your body, palms up.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
Hold for the desired duration.
description: A restorative yoga pose that gently stretches the back, hips, and shoulders.

name: Thread the Needle Stretch
instructions: Start on your hands and knees (quadruped position).
Inhale and reach your right arm up towards the ceiling, opening your chest.
Exhale and 'thread' your right arm underneath your left armpit, lowering your right shoulder and ear towards the floor.
Keep your hips stable and centered.
You can keep your left hand on the floor or extend it forward.
Hold the stretch, breathing deeply.
Unwind and return to the starting position.
Repeat on the other side.
description: A stretch targeting thoracic spine rotation and shoulder mobility.

name: Downward-Facing Dog
instructions: Start on your hands and knees.
Tuck your toes under and lift your hips up and back, straightening your legs as much as comfortable.
Form an inverted V-shape with your body.
Press your hands firmly into the floor, spreading your fingers.
Keep your head between your arms, looking towards your feet or navel.
Try to press your heels towards the floor (they may not reach).
Hold the pose, breathing deeply.
description: A foundational yoga pose that stretches the hamstrings, calves, shoulders, and back.

name: Upward-Facing Dog
instructions: Lie prone (face down) on the floor, legs extended back, tops of feet on the floor.
Place your hands under your shoulders, fingers pointing forward.
Inhale and press through your hands, straightening your arms and lifting your torso and hips off the floor.
Keep your shoulders down and back, away from your ears.
Press the tops of your feet firmly into the floor.
Look straight ahead or slightly upward.
Hold the pose, engaging your legs and core.
description: A yoga backbend that stretches the chest, shoulders, and abdominals while strengthening the arms and back.

name: Cobra Stretch
instructions: Lie prone (face down) on the floor, legs extended back, tops of feet on the floor.
Place your hands under your shoulders, elbows tucked close to your body.
Inhale and gently press through your hands to lift your head, chest, and shoulders off the floor.
Keep your hips and legs on the floor.
Keep your elbows slightly bent.
Draw your shoulders down and back, away from your ears.
Look straight ahead or slightly upward.
Hold the stretch gently.
description: A gentle backbend that stretches the chest and front of the shoulders, improving spinal mobility.

name: Quadruped Thoracic Rotations
instructions: Start on your hands and knees, hands under shoulders, knees under hips.
Place one hand behind your head, elbow pointing out to the side.
Keeping your core stable and lower back neutral, rotate your torso.
Bring the elbow of the raised arm down towards the opposite wrist.
Reverse the movement, rotating upwards and pointing the elbow towards the ceiling, opening your chest.
Follow your elbow with your eyes.
Perform slowly and controlled.
Complete reps on one side, then switch.
description: An exercise performed on all fours to improve rotational mobility in the upper back (thoracic spine).

name: Bird Dog
instructions: Start on your hands and knees, hands under shoulders, knees under hips, back flat.
Engage your core to keep your torso stable.
Simultaneously extend your right arm straight forward and your left leg straight back.
Keep your hips and shoulders square to the floor, avoiding rotation.
Reach long through your fingertips and heel.
Hold briefly.
Slowly return to the starting position.
Repeat with the opposite arm and leg (left arm, right leg).
Continue alternating sides.
description: A core stability exercise that challenges balance and coordination while strengthening the core, glutes, and back.

name: Dead Bug
instructions: Lie on your back with arms extended towards the ceiling, perpendicular to the floor.
Bring your knees up so your hips and knees are bent at 90 degrees (tabletop position).
Engage your core, pressing your lower back gently into the floor.
Slowly lower your right arm straight back towards the floor behind your head while simultaneously extending your left leg straight out.
Lower as far as you can maintain core control and keep your lower back on the floor.
Return the arm and leg to the starting position.
Repeat with the opposite arm and leg (left arm, right leg).
Continue alternating sides slowly and with control.
description: A core exercise focusing on lumbo-pelvic stability and coordinating opposite limb movements.

name: Glute Bridge
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart, close to your glutes.
Place your arms by your sides, palms down.
Engage your core and glutes.
Press through your heels to lift your hips off the floor until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees.
Squeeze your glutes at the top.
Avoid arching your lower back excessively.
Slowly lower your hips back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
description: A fundamental exercise to activate and strengthen the gluteal muscles and hamstrings.

name: Glute Bridge Walkouts
instructions: Start in the top position of a glute bridge (hips lifted, body in a straight line from shoulders to knees).
Keeping your hips elevated and core engaged, take small steps forward with your feet, walking them away from your body.
Walk out as far as you can while maintaining hip height and control.
Once extended, take small steps back, walking your feet back towards your glutes.
Keep hips up throughout the movement.
Repeat the walkout and walk-in process.
description: A variation of the glute bridge that increases hamstring engagement by walking the feet out and back.

name: Inchworm
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart.
Hinge at your hips and lower your hands towards the floor, keeping legs as straight as possible.
Once hands touch the floor, walk them forward, keeping legs straight, until you reach a high plank position.
Hold the plank briefly, maintaining a straight line from head to heels.
Keeping hands in place, take small steps with your feet, walking them towards your hands.
Keep legs as straight as possible during the walk-in.
Return to a standing position or repeat by walking hands out again.
Alternatively, walk hands back to feet from plank position.
description: A dynamic exercise that stretches the hamstrings and calves while warming up the shoulders and core.

name: Spiderman Stretch
instructions: Start in a high plank position.
Step your right foot forward to the outside of your right hand, entering a deep lunge position.
Try to keep your back leg straight and engaged, or lower the back knee for less intensity.
Sink your hips down towards the floor, feeling a stretch in the hip flexors of the back leg and the groin/hip of the front leg.
Keep your chest up.
Hold the stretch.
Step the right foot back to the plank position.
Repeat by stepping the left foot forward to the outside of the left hand.
Alternate sides.
description: A deep lunge variation that effectively stretches the hip flexors, groin, and hamstrings.

name: Spiderman Stretch with Rotation
instructions: Start in the Spiderman Stretch position (e.g., right foot outside right hand).
Keep your left hand planted firmly on the floor.
Rotate your torso towards your front leg (right).
Reach your right arm up towards the ceiling, opening your chest.
Follow your hand with your eyes.
Hold the rotation briefly.
Bring the right hand back down inside the right foot.
Step the right foot back to plank.
Repeat on the other side (left foot forward, rotate and reach left arm up).
description: Combines the hip-opening Spiderman Stretch with upper back rotation for enhanced mobility.

name: World's Greatest Stretch
instructions: Start standing and step forward into a deep lunge with your right foot.
Place both hands on the floor inside your right foot.
Lower your right elbow towards the floor inside your right foot (Spiderman Lunge).
Place your left hand firmly on the floor.
Rotate your torso to the right, reaching your right arm towards the ceiling (Thoracic Rotation).
Bring your right hand back to the floor.
Push your hips back, straightening your front leg as much as possible to stretch the hamstring.
Return to the lunge position.
Step back to standing or plank and repeat on the left side.
description: A comprehensive mobility sequence combining a lunge, hip flexor stretch, hamstring stretch, and thoracic rotation.

name: Deep Squat Hold
instructions: Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointed slightly outwards.
Lower your hips down into a deep squat position, going as low as comfortable while maintaining good form.
Keep your chest up and back straight.
Try to keep heels on the ground (use support under heels if needed).
You can rest your elbows inside your knees, gently pushing them outwards.
Hold the bottom position, focusing on relaxing into the stretch.
Use a support (like holding onto a pole or TRX) if needed for balance or depth (assisted).
description: Holding the bottom position of a squat to improve hip, ankle, and groin mobility.

name: Dynamic Hamstring Kicks
instructions: Stand tall.
Extend one arm straight forward at shoulder height.
Keeping your leg relatively straight (slight bend in the knee is okay), swing the opposite leg forward, attempting to kick your hand.
Control the swing, avoiding jerky movements.
Lower the leg back down.
Repeat with the same leg for desired reps or alternate legs with each kick.
Focus on the stretch felt in the hamstring during the upward swing.
description: A dynamic stretch involving controlled leg kicks to warm up the hamstrings.

name: Standing Hamstring Scoops
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart.
Step forward slightly with one foot, placing the heel on the ground with toes pointing up.
Keep the front leg mostly straight and slightly bend the back knee.
Hinge at your hips, keeping your back straight, and reach down towards the toes of the front foot as if scooping something off the floor.
Feel the stretch in the hamstring of the front leg.
Return to the upright position.
Step forward with the other foot and repeat the scoop.
Continue alternating legs as you walk forward slowly.
description: A dynamic stretch involving hinging at the hips and reaching towards the front foot to target the hamstrings.

name: Standing Quad Stretch
instructions: Stand tall near a wall or support for balance if needed.
Shift your weight onto one leg.
Bend the opposite knee and bring the heel towards your glutes.
Reach back with the same-side hand (or opposite hand for variation) and grasp your ankle or foot.
Gently pull your heel closer to your glute, keeping your knees close together.
Keep your torso upright and avoid arching your back.
Feel the stretch in the front of your thigh.
Hold for the desired duration.
Release slowly and repeat on the other leg.
description: A static stretch targeting the quadriceps muscle group.

name: Kneeling Hip Flexor Stretch
instructions: Kneel on one knee (place padding under the knee if needed), with the other foot planted flat on the floor in front of you, knee bent at 90 degrees.
Ensure your front knee is aligned over your ankle.
Keep your torso upright and engage your core.
Gently tuck your tailbone under (posterior pelvic tilt) and shift your hips slightly forward.
Feel the stretch in the front of the hip of the kneeling leg.
Avoid leaning forward excessively from the waist.
Hold the stretch.
For a deeper stretch, reach the arm on the kneeling side overhead.
Switch legs and repeat.
description: A stretch targeting the hip flexor muscles, often tight from sitting.

name: Standing Calf Stretch
instructions: Stand facing a wall, about arm's length away.
Place your hands on the wall for support.
Step one foot back, keeping the heel flat on the floor and the leg straight (stretches gastrocnemius).
Lean forward slightly, keeping the back heel down.
Hold the stretch.
To target the soleus, slightly bend the back knee while keeping the heel down.
Hold the stretch.
Switch legs and repeat both variations (straight leg and bent knee).
description: A static stretch for the calf muscles (gastrocnemius and soleus) using a wall for support.

name: Dynamic Calf Raises/Drops
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, near a wall or support for balance if needed.
Slowly rise up onto the balls of your feet, lifting your heels as high as possible (calf raise).
Hold briefly at the top.
Slowly lower your heels back down to the floor.
For heel drops (more stretch), stand with the balls of your feet on the edge of a step or elevated surface.
Lower your heels below the level of the step, feeling a stretch.
Raise back up onto the balls of your feet.
Repeat the raising and lowering motion.
description: A dynamic exercise involving raising and lowering the heels to warm up and stretch the calf muscles and ankles.

name: Wall Slides
instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, feet slightly away from the wall.
Try to maintain contact with the wall with your lower back, upper back, and head.
Bend your elbows to 90 degrees and raise your arms so your upper arms are parallel to the floor.
Press your forearms and the backs of your hands against the wall.
Slowly slide your arms upwards along the wall, keeping contact with forearms and hands as much as possible.
Go as high as you can without losing contact or arching your lower back.
Slowly slide your arms back down to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: An exercise performed against a wall to improve shoulder mobility, external rotation, and scapular control.

name: Scapular Push-ups
instructions: Start in a high plank position (or on hands and knees for easier variation), arms straight, hands under shoulders.
Keep your arms straight throughout the movement.
Allow your chest to sink towards the floor by squeezing your shoulder blades together (retraction).
Push through your hands, rounding your upper back slightly and spreading your shoulder blades apart (protraction).
Focus solely on the movement of the shoulder blades, keeping elbows locked.
Repeat the retraction and protraction sequence.
description: An exercise focusing on controlled shoulder blade movement (protraction and retraction) to improve scapular stability.

name: Scapular Pull-ups
instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Keep your arms straight and body relaxed in a dead hang (elevation - shoulders shrugged up).
Without bending your elbows, pull your shoulder blades down and back (depression).
Imagine trying to pull the bar down using only your shoulder blades.
Your body should lift slightly.
Hold the depressed position briefly.
Slowly relax back into the dead hang position (elevation).
Repeat the depression and elevation sequence.
description: An exercise performed while hanging to activate and strengthen the muscles responsible for shoulder blade depression.

name: Plank (Short Hold)
instructions: For Forearm Plank: Place forearms on the ground, elbows directly under shoulders, hands clasped or flat.
For High Plank: Place hands on the ground directly under shoulders, arms straight.
Extend legs back, resting on toes.
Engage your core, glutes, and quads to form a straight line from head to heels.
Avoid letting hips sag or rise too high.
Keep neck in line with spine.
Hold the position for a short duration (e.g., 15-30 seconds).
description: A core isometric exercise to build core strength and stability, performed for short durations as part of a warm-up.

name: Side Plank (Short Hold)
instructions: Lie on your side with legs straight, stacked or staggered for more stability.
Place your bottom forearm on the floor, elbow directly under your shoulder.
Engage your core and lift your hips off the floor until your body forms a straight line from head to feet.
Keep your hips square and avoid rotating.
You can place your top hand on your hip or extend it towards the ceiling.
Hold the position for a short duration (e.g., 15-30 seconds).
Lower hips slowly.
Repeat on the other side.
description: An isometric exercise targeting the obliques and core stability, performed for short durations during warm-up.

name: Bear Crawl
instructions: Start on your hands and knees, hands under shoulders, knees under hips.
Lift your knees slightly off the floor, keeping your back flat and core engaged.
Move forward by moving your right hand and left foot simultaneously.
Then move your left hand and right foot simultaneously.
Take small, controlled steps.
Keep your hips low and stable.
Crawl forward for a short distance, then you can crawl backward.
description: A quadrupedal movement pattern that challenges core stability, coordination, and shoulder/hip strength.

name: Crab Walk
instructions: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet flat on the ground, hip-width apart.
Place your hands on the floor behind you, fingers pointing towards your feet or slightly outwards.
Lift your hips off the floor.
Walk forward by moving your right hand and left foot, then left hand and right foot.
Alternatively, walk backward leading with feet.
Keep your hips lifted and core engaged.
Move for a short distance.
description: A bodyweight movement involving walking on hands and feet with the chest facing up, warming up shoulders, triceps, and core.

name: Jumping Jacks (Light)
instructions: Stand with feet together and arms at your sides.
Simultaneously jump your feet out to the sides (wider than shoulder-width) while raising your arms overhead.
Jump back to the starting position, bringing feet together and arms back to sides.
Perform at a light, controlled pace suitable for a warm-up.
Maintain rhythmic breathing.
description: A classic full-body aerobic exercise used to elevate heart rate and warm up muscles.

name: Seal Jacks
instructions: Stand with feet together, arms extended straight out in front of you at chest height, palms facing each other.
Simultaneously jump your feet out to the sides (wider than shoulder-width) while swinging your arms horizontally out to the sides (like clapping in reverse).
Jump back to the starting position, bringing feet together and arms back to the front, clapping hands lightly.
Keep arms at chest height throughout.
Maintain a rhythmic pace.
description: A variation of jumping jacks involving horizontal arm movement, warming up the chest and shoulders.

name: Cross Jacks
instructions: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, arms extended out to the sides at shoulder height.
Jump your feet together, crossing one foot in front of the other.
Simultaneously cross your arms in front of your chest.
Jump back to the starting position (feet wide, arms out).
On the next jump, cross the opposite foot in front and the opposite arm on top.
Continue alternating the crossing pattern.
description: A jumping jack variation involving crossing arms and legs, enhancing coordination and warming up.

name: Foam Rolling: Quads
instructions: Lie face down, placing the foam roller under the front of your thighs (quadriceps).
Support your upper body on your forearms.
Use your arms to slowly roll your body back and forth, moving the roller along the length of your quads, from just above the knee to the hip.
Pause briefly on any particularly tight or tender spots, applying gentle pressure.
You can slightly rotate your body inwards or outwards to target different areas of the quads.
Roll slowly for 30-60 seconds.
description: Using a foam roller to apply pressure to the quadriceps muscles, aiming to release tension and improve tissue quality.

name: Foam Rolling: Hamstrings
instructions: Sit on the floor with legs extended, placing the foam roller under your hamstrings (back of thighs).
Place your hands on the floor behind you for support.
Lift your hips off the floor.
Use your hands to slowly roll back and forth, moving the roller along the length of your hamstrings, from just above the back of the knee to below the glutes.
Pause on tender spots.
You can roll one leg at a time by crossing the other leg over for more pressure.
Roll slowly for 30-60 seconds per leg.
description: Using a foam roller on the hamstrings to release muscle tightness.

name: Foam Rolling: Glutes/Piriformis
instructions: Sit on the foam roller with knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Lean onto one glute (e.g., the right glute), placing your hands behind you for support.
Cross the ankle of the targeted glute over the opposite knee (right ankle over left knee for right glute).
Slowly roll back and forth over the glute muscle.
Adjust your body angle to find tender spots, often deeper in the hip (piriformis area).
Pause on tender spots.
Roll slowly for 30-60 seconds per side.
description: Using a foam roller to target the gluteal muscles and the deeper piriformis muscle for myofascial release.

name: Foam Rolling: Calves
instructions: Sit on the floor with legs extended, placing the foam roller under your calves.
Place hands behind you for support and lift your hips off the floor.
Slowly roll back and forth from the ankles to just below the knees.
Rotate your legs inward and outward to target different parts of the calf muscle.
Pause on tender spots.
Cross one leg over the other for increased pressure.
Roll slowly for 30-60 seconds per leg.
description: Using a foam roller on the calf muscles to release tension and improve flexibility.

name: Foam Rolling: Thoracic Spine
instructions: Lie on your back with the foam roller positioned horizontally across your upper back (below the neck, above the lower back).
Bend your knees and place feet flat on the floor.
Support your head with your hands (interlace fingers behind head) or cross arms over chest.
Lift your hips slightly off the floor.
Use your legs to slowly roll back and forth, moving the roller along your upper and mid-back.
Avoid rolling onto your neck or lower back.
Pause on tight spots, you can gently arch back over the roller for added mobilization.
Roll slowly for 30-60 seconds.
description: Using a foam roller to mobilize the thoracic spine and release tension in the upper back muscles.

name: Foam Rolling: Lats
instructions: Lie on your side with the foam roller placed under your armpit area, slightly towards your back (targeting the latissimus dorsi).
Extend your bottom arm overhead along the floor.
Use your top leg and top arm for support and control.
Slowly roll up and down the side of your torso, from the armpit down towards the mid-back.
Lean back slightly to better target the lat muscle.
Pause on tender spots.
Roll slowly for 30-60 seconds per side.
description: Using a foam roller to target the latissimus dorsi muscles on the side of the back for myofascial release.

name: Lacrosse Ball: Pec Minor
instructions: Stand facing a wall or door frame.
Place a lacrosse ball on the upper, outer part of your chest, just below the collarbone and inside the shoulder joint (pec minor area).
Lean into the wall, applying pressure to the ball.
Slowly move your body side-to-side or up-and-down to massage the area.
You can also perform slow arm movements (like raising the arm) while applying pressure.
Focus on tender spots, apply sustained pressure or small movements.
Perform for 30-60 seconds per side.
description: Using a lacrosse ball against a wall to target the small pectoralis minor muscle for trigger point release.

name: Lacrosse Ball: Glute Medius
instructions: Sit on the floor or stand against a wall.
Place the lacrosse ball under the upper, outer part of your glute (gluteus medius area, below the hip bone).
If sitting, lean onto the ball, supporting yourself with hands.
If standing, lean against the wall with the ball between your hip and the wall.
Slowly roll the ball around the area or apply sustained pressure to tender spots.
You can cross the ankle over the opposite knee to deepen the pressure.
Perform for 30-60 seconds per side.
description: Using a lacrosse ball to target the gluteus medius muscle on the side of the hip for trigger point release.

name: Lacrosse Ball: Plantar Fascia
instructions: Sit on a chair or stand.
Place a lacrosse ball under the arch of one foot.
Apply downward pressure onto the ball.
Slowly roll the ball back and forth along the length of the arch, from the heel towards the toes.
Pause and apply sustained pressure on any tender spots.
Control the pressure by adjusting your body weight.
Perform for 30-60 seconds per foot.
description: Using a lacrosse ball to massage the plantar fascia on the sole of the foot, relieving tightness.

name: Banded Ankle Mobilization
instructions: Secure a resistance band low down on a sturdy anchor point.
Step inside the loop and place the band around your ankle, just above the joint on the front side.
Step back to create tension in the band.
Assume a half-kneeling or standing lunge position with the banded ankle forward.
Keeping your heel down, drive your knee forward over your toes, using the band's pull to assist the ankle joint's glide.
Focus on increasing dorsiflexion (shin moving closer to foot).
Perform slow, controlled pulses or hold the stretch.
Repeat for reps or time, then switch ankles.
description: Using a resistance band to improve ankle dorsiflexion mobility by mobilizing the talus bone.

name: Banded Lateral Walks
instructions: Place a looped resistance band around your ankles, knees, or thighs (higher placement is generally easier).
Stand with feet hip-width apart, creating tension in the band.
Assume an athletic stance: slight bend in knees and hips, chest up, core engaged.
Take controlled steps sideways, maintaining tension on the band.
Keep feet pointing forward and avoid letting knees cave inward.
Take a set number of steps in one direction, then return by stepping the other way.
Focus on feeling the activation in the sides of your hips/glutes.
description: An exercise using a resistance band to activate the hip abductor muscles, particularly the gluteus medius.

name: Banded Glute Bridges
instructions: Place a looped resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees.
Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor hip-width apart, arms by sides.
Actively push your knees outwards against the band to maintain tension.
Engage your core and glutes.
Press through your heels to lift your hips off the floor, forming a straight line from shoulders to knees.
Maintain outward pressure on the band throughout the movement, especially at the top.
Squeeze your glutes at the top.
Slowly lower your hips back down.
Repeat.
description: A glute bridge variation using a resistance band around the thighs to increase gluteus medius activation.

name: Clamshells
instructions: Lie on your side with knees bent at approximately 90 degrees and hips stacked.
Your feet should be in line with your spine.
You can rest your head on your bottom arm.
Keep your feet together.
Engage your core to keep your pelvis stable (prevent rolling back).
Lift your top knee upwards towards the ceiling, rotating at the hip joint, like a clamshell opening.
Go as high as you can without letting your pelvis roll backward.
Focus on using the outer hip muscles.
Slowly lower the knee back down.
Repeat for reps, then switch sides. (Can add a band around thighs for resistance).
description: A hip external rotation exercise targeting the gluteus medius, often used for activation and strengthening.

name: Fire Hydrants
instructions: Start on your hands and knees, hands under shoulders, knees under hips.
Keep your back flat and core engaged.
Keeping your knee bent at 90 degrees, lift one leg out to the side, away from your body.
Lift as high as possible without shifting your weight excessively or rotating your torso.
Focus on initiating the movement from the hip/glute.
Hold briefly at the top.
Slowly lower the knee back to the starting position.
Repeat for reps, then switch sides. (Can add a band around thighs for resistance).
description: A hip abduction exercise performed on all fours, targeting the gluteus medius and minimus.

name: Superman/Prone Swimmers
instructions: Lie face down on the floor with arms and legs extended (Superman starting position).
Engage your lower back, glutes, and hamstrings to simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the floor.
Keep your neck in line with your spine, looking down or slightly forward.
Hold this 'Superman' pose briefly, then lower.
For 'Swimmers': From the lifted position (or starting from the floor), perform small, alternating flutter kicks with your arms and legs, mimicking a swimming motion.
Keep core engaged and movements controlled.
Perform for reps or time.
description: Exercises performed lying prone to strengthen the posterior chain, including the lower back, glutes, and hamstrings.

name: Lying Scorpion Stretch
instructions: Lie face down on the floor with arms extended out to the sides in a 'T' shape, palms down.
Keep your chest and shoulders pressed towards the floor.
Bend your right knee.
Lift your right leg up and across your body, trying to touch your right foot towards your left hand.
Allow your hips and lower back to rotate, but keep your shoulders as flat as possible.
Feel the stretch through your spine, chest, and potentially the hip flexor of the bent leg.
Hold briefly.
Return to the starting position.
Repeat on the other side, lifting the left leg towards the right hand.
Alternate sides.
description: A dynamic stretch involving spinal rotation while lying prone, improving mobility and stretching the chest/shoulders.

name: Standing Side Bends
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart, core engaged.
Place one hand on your hip and extend the other arm overhead.
Alternatively, keep both hands by your sides.
Slowly bend your torso directly to one side, reaching the overhead arm over or sliding the other hand down your leg.
Feel the stretch along the opposite side of your waist.
Keep your chest open and avoid leaning forward or backward.
Return to the upright position.
Repeat on the other side or complete reps on one side before switching.
Can hold light dumbbells for added resistance.
description: A stretch targeting the oblique muscles and improving lateral spinal flexibility.

name: Figure Four Stretch
instructions: Seated: Sit upright on a chair or the floor.
Cross your right ankle over your left knee/thigh, creating a 'figure four' shape.
Keep your right foot flexed to protect the knee.
Gently press down on your right knee OR lean your torso forward over your legs to deepen the stretch.
Feel the stretch in your right glute/hip.
Hold.
Standing: Stand tall, find balance (use support if needed).
Cross your right ankle over your left thigh, just above the knee.
Bend your standing knee and sit your hips back as if sitting in a chair.
Keep your chest up and back straight.
Hold.
Repeat on the other side for both variations.
description: A stretch targeting the glutes and piriformis muscle, performed either seated or standing.

name: Bodyweight Squat
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outwards.
Keep your chest up and core engaged.
Lower your hips back and down as if sitting into a chair.
Ensure knees track in line with toes.
Lower until thighs are parallel to the ground or as low as comfortable.
Push through your heels to return to the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
description: A fundamental lower body exercise using only bodyweight, targeting quads and glutes.

name: Bodyweight Pause Squat
instructions: Perform a bodyweight squat as described.
At the bottom of the squat (thighs parallel or below), hold the position for a specified count (e.g., 1-3 seconds).
Maintain tension and proper form during the pause.
Drive back up to the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
description: A bodyweight squat variation involving a pause at the bottom to increase time under tension and control.

name: Bodyweight Tempo Squat
instructions: Perform a bodyweight squat using a specific tempo for different phases of the lift.
Example tempo (4-1-2-0): Lower down over 4 seconds, pause for 1 second at the bottom, rise up over 2 seconds, no pause at the top.
Maintain control throughout the prescribed tempo.
Focus on smooth transitions between phases.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
description: A bodyweight squat performed with controlled timing for lowering, pausing, and lifting phases to enhance muscle control.

name: Goblet Squat
instructions: Hold a single dumbbell or kettlebell vertically against your chest, cupping the top end with both hands.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out.
Keep the weight close to your chest and maintain an upright torso.
Lower into a squat, pushing hips back and bending knees.
Keep elbows tucked inside knees at the bottom.
Drive through heels to return to standing.
Repeat.
description: A squat variation holding a weight at chest level, promoting an upright torso and targeting quads and glutes.

name: Dumbbell Front Squat
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand.
Rest the dumbbells on the front of your shoulders, palms facing each other or towards your body.
Keep elbows up and pointed forward.
Engage your core and maintain an upright torso.
Lower into a squat, keeping the dumbbells stable on your shoulders.
Drive through heels to return to standing.
Repeat.
description: A front-loaded squat using two dumbbells held at the shoulders, emphasizing quadriceps and core strength.

name: Barbell Front Squat
instructions: Approach the barbell in a squat rack set at upper chest height.
Position the bar across the front of your shoulders, resting it on the deltoids.
Use either a clean grip (fingertips under the bar outside shoulders) or a cross-arm grip.
Keep elbows high and parallel to the ground.
Unrack the bar, step back, feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out.
Maintain an upright torso and squat down, pushing hips back.
Keep elbows high throughout the movement.
Drive through heels to return to standing.
Repeat.
description: A squat variation with the barbell held across the front of the shoulders, heavily targeting the quads and upper back.

name: Barbell Back Squat (High Bar)
instructions: Set the barbell in a rack at upper back height.
Position the bar high on your trapezius muscles (traps).
Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Unrack the bar, step back, feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out.
Keep chest up, core braced.
Initiate the squat by pushing hips back and bending knees simultaneously.
Maintain a relatively upright torso.
Lower until thighs are at least parallel to the floor.
Drive through the mid-foot/heels to return to standing.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental strength exercise where the barbell rests high on the traps, emphasizing quadriceps development.

name: Barbell Back Squat (Low Bar)
instructions: Set the barbell in a rack slightly lower than for high bar.
Position the bar across your rear deltoids, creating a 'shelf' with your upper back muscles.
Grip the bar (often slightly narrower than high bar).
Unrack the bar, step back, feet shoulder-width apart or slightly wider.
Keep core braced.
Initiate the squat by pushing hips back significantly, allowing for more forward torso lean than high bar.
Lower until hip crease is below the top of the knee.
Focus on driving hips up out of the bottom.
Drive through mid-foot/heels to return to standing.
Repeat.
description: A back squat variation where the bar rests lower on the back, allowing for more weight and emphasizing posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings).

name: Overhead Squat
instructions: Grip a barbell (or dumbbells/plate) with a wide (snatch) grip.
Press or lift the weight overhead, locking elbows and stabilizing shoulders.
Maintain the weight directly overhead, aligned with mid-foot.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out.
Keep core braced and torso upright.
Squat down, maintaining the weight overhead and stable.
Lower to desired depth while keeping balance and form.
Drive through heels to return to standing.
Repeat.
description: A challenging squat variation requiring significant mobility, stability, and strength, with the weight held overhead.

name: Zercher Squat
instructions: Set a barbell in a rack around waist height.
Position the bar in the crook of your elbows, clasping hands together in front.
Lift the bar out of the rack.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Maintain an upright torso and keep the bar secure in your elbows.
Squat down, pushing hips back.
Keep your back straight and core tight.
Drive back up to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: An unconventional squat where the barbell is held in the crook of the elbows, heavily engaging the upper back and core.

name: Box Squat
instructions: Place a box or bench behind you at the desired squat depth.
Set up for a back squat (high or low bar) or hold dumbbells.
Initiate the squat by pushing hips back significantly.
Lower down until your glutes lightly touch the box, maintaining tension.
Pause briefly on the box without fully relaxing.
Drive upwards explosively, leading with the chest.
Repeat.
description: A squat variation where you squat down to touch a box, emphasizing posterior chain engagement and breaking the eccentric/concentric chain.

name: Pause Squat (Barbell)
instructions: Perform a barbell front or back squat.
At the bottom of the squat, pause for a predetermined duration (e.g., 1-3 seconds).
Maintain core brace, muscle tension, and proper form during the pause.
Avoid bouncing out of the bottom.
Drive up powerfully after the pause.
Repeat.
description: A barbell squat (front or back) with an intentional pause at the bottom to build strength and control in that position.

name: Tempo Squat (Barbell)
instructions: Perform a barbell front or back squat using a specific tempo (e.g., 3 seconds down, 1 second pause, 2 seconds up).
Control the barbell throughout each phase according to the prescribed timing.
Maintain consistent form and tension.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
description: A barbell squat (front or back) performed with controlled timing for eccentric, isometric, and concentric phases.

name: Safety Bar Squat
instructions: Position a safety squat bar on your shoulders, holding the handles in front.
The camber and padding distribute the weight differently than a straight bar.
Unrack the bar, step back, feet shoulder-width apart.
The bar tends to pitch you forward; resist this by keeping your chest up and core tight.
Squat down, maintaining control.
Drive back up to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A squat variation using a specialized safety squat bar, challenging the upper back and quads, often easier on the shoulders.

name: Smith Machine Squat
instructions: Position yourself under the bar of a Smith machine, resting it on your upper back (high or low position).
Place feet shoulder-width apart, potentially slightly forward of the bar's path.
Unlatch the bar.
Keeping your back straight and core engaged, lower down by bending knees and hips.
The machine guides the bar path.
Lower to desired depth.
Push back up to the starting position.
Latch the bar at the top if needed.
Repeat.
description: A squat performed within a Smith machine, providing stability and guiding the bar path.

name: Pin Squat
instructions: Set the safety pins in a squat rack at a specific partial height (e.g., slightly above parallel).
Place the barbell on the pins.
Get under the bar, setting up as you would for a squat.
Lift the bar off the pins by driving up.
Lower the bar back down until it rests completely on the pins (dead stop).
Relax briefly, then re-engage and drive up powerfully from the pins.
Repeat.
description: A squat variation starting and ending each rep from a dead stop on safety pins set at a specific height.

name: Anderson Squat
instructions: Set the safety pins in a squat rack at the bottom position of your squat.
Place the barbell on the pins.
Get under the bar while in the bottom squat position.
Create tension, brace your core, and drive the bar straight up off the pins.
Lower the bar back down under control until it rests completely on the pins.
Reset your position and tension for each rep.
Repeat.
description: A squat variation starting each repetition from a dead stop at the very bottom position, resting on pins.

name: Jump Squat
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Lower into a squat position (partial or full depth).
Explosively drive upwards, extending hips, knees, and ankles to jump off the ground.
Land softly by absorbing the impact through your legs, returning to the squat position.
Reset between jumps or perform continuously.
Focus on explosive power and soft landings.
description: A plyometric exercise involving jumping explosively from a squat position to develop lower body power.

name: Squat Jump (Continuous)
instructions: Perform jump squats repeatedly without pausing between repetitions.
Lower into a squat.
Immediately jump explosively upwards.
Land softly and immediately transition into the next squat.
Maintain a rhythm and focus on continuous movement.
Perform for a set number of reps or time.
description: Repeated jump squats performed without rest, focusing on explosive power and muscular endurance.

name: Box Jump
instructions: Stand facing a sturdy box of appropriate height.
Feet shoulder-width apart, a comfortable distance from the box.
Lower into a partial squat, swinging arms back.
Explosively swing arms forward and jump upwards and forwards, extending hips, knees, and ankles.
Land softly on the box with knees bent.
Stand up fully on the box.
Step down (do not jump down) carefully.
Reset and repeat.
description: A plyometric exercise involving jumping onto an elevated box to improve explosive lower body power.

name: Depth Jump
instructions: Stand on top of a sturdy box (start with a low height).
Step off the edge of the box (do not jump off).
Land on the balls of both feet simultaneously.
Immediately upon landing, explode vertically, jumping as high as possible.
Minimize ground contact time.
Land softly from the jump.
Reset and repeat.
description: An advanced plyometric exercise involving dropping off a box and immediately jumping vertically to enhance reactive strength.

name: Broad Jump
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Lower into a partial squat, swinging arms back.
Explosively swing arms forward and jump horizontally as far as possible.
Extend hips, knees, and ankles fully.
Land softly on both feet simultaneously, absorbing the impact by bending knees and hips.
Try to stick the landing without falling forward or backward.
Measure distance if desired.
Reset and repeat.
description: A plyometric exercise involving jumping horizontally for maximum distance, developing explosive hip extension power.

name: Tuck Jump
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Lower into a slight squat.
Explosively jump vertically as high as possible.
While in the air, quickly pull your knees towards your chest (tuck position).
Extend legs back down before landing.
Land softly, absorbing the impact.
Reset or perform continuously.
Repeat.
description: A plyometric jump involving tucking the knees towards the chest at the peak of the jump.

name: Reverse Lunge
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. (Optionally hold DBs or BB).
Engage your core.
Step backward with one leg, landing on the ball of your foot.
Lower your hips until both knees are bent at approximately 90 degrees.
Ensure your front knee stays aligned over your ankle and your back knee hovers just above the floor.
Push off the back foot and drive through the front heel to return to the starting position.
Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A lunge variation where you step backward, often considered slightly easier on the knees than forward lunges.

name: Forward Lunge
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. (Optionally hold DBs or BB).
Engage your core.
Step forward with one leg, planting your foot firmly.
Lower your hips until both knees are bent at approximately 90 degrees.
Ensure your front knee is over your ankle and your back knee is close to the floor.
Keep your torso upright.
Push off the front foot to return to the starting position.
Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental lunge variation involving stepping forward into the lunge position.

name: Walking Lunge
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. (Optionally hold DBs or BB).
Step forward with one leg into a lunge position (both knees bent ~90 degrees).
Instead of pushing back, push off the back foot and bring it forward to meet the front foot, returning to a standing position.
Immediately step forward with the other leg into the next lunge.
Continue alternating legs as you walk forward.
Maintain balance and control.
Repeat for desired distance or reps.
description: A dynamic lunge variation where you continuously step forward into lunges, moving across the floor.

name: Lateral Lunge
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. (Optionally hold DBs).
Take a large step directly to one side (e.g., right).
Keeping the trailing leg (left) straight, bend the knee of the stepping leg (right) and push your hips back.
Lower down until the thigh of the bent leg is close to parallel with the floor.
Keep your torso upright and chest up.
Push off the bent leg (right) to return to the starting position.
Repeat on the other side or complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A lunge performed by stepping sideways, effectively targeting the inner thighs (adductors) and glutes.

name: Curtsy Lunge
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. (Optionally hold DBs).
Step one leg (e.g., right) diagonally backward behind the other leg (left).
Lower your hips until your front thigh (left) is nearly parallel to the floor.
Your front knee should track over your ankle.
Keep your torso upright and core engaged.
Push off the back foot and return to the starting position.
Alternate sides or complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A lunge variation involving stepping diagonally backward, targeting the glutes, particularly the gluteus medius.

name: Split Squat
instructions: Start in a staggered stance, one foot forward and one foot back, feet hip-width apart.
Keep your torso upright and core engaged. (Optionally hold DBs or BB).
Lower your body straight down by bending both knees, until your back knee is close to the floor.
Your front knee should form approximately a 90-degree angle and stay over the ankle.
Your back heel will be lifted.
Push through the front foot to return to the starting position.
Keep feet in the same position throughout the set.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A stationary lunge where the feet remain in place, focusing work on the front leg.

name: Bulgarian Split Squat
instructions: Stand a few feet in front of a bench or elevated surface.
Place the top of one foot on the bench behind you.
Your front foot should be far enough forward so that when you lower, your knee stays roughly over your ankle.
Keep your torso upright and core engaged. (Optionally hold DBs or BB).
Lower your body down by bending your front knee until your front thigh is parallel or lower.
Push through your front foot to return to the starting position.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A split squat variation with the rear foot elevated, increasing the range of motion and demand on the front leg.

name: Split Squat Jump
instructions: Start in a split squat or lunge position.
Lower down into the lunge.
Explosively jump upwards, switching the position of your legs in mid-air.
Land softly in a lunge position with the opposite leg forward.
Immediately lower into the next lunge and repeat the jump.
Continue alternating legs with each jump.
Maintain balance and control.
description: A plyometric exercise involving jumping and switching leg positions from a lunge stance.

name: Step-Up
instructions: Stand facing a sturdy box or bench of appropriate height. (Optionally hold DBs or BB).
Place one entire foot firmly on the box.
Engage your core.
Drive through the heel of the foot on the box to lift your body up until your leg is straight.
Bring the other foot onto the box or keep it trailing.
Minimize pushing off with the back leg; focus work on the leading leg.
Step back down carefully with the trailing leg first.
Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: An exercise involving stepping onto an elevated surface, primarily working the lead leg's quads and glutes.

name: Lateral Step-Up
instructions: Stand sideways next to a sturdy box or bench. (Optionally hold DBs).
Place the foot closest to the box firmly onto the surface.
Engage your core.
Drive through the heel of the foot on the box, stepping up laterally until that leg is straight.
Focus on using the hip muscles of the stepping leg.
Bring the other foot onto the box or keep it trailing.
Step back down laterally under control.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A step-up performed sideways, emphasizing the outer hip muscles (gluteus medius) of the lead leg.

name: Pistol Squat
instructions: Stand on one leg, extending the other leg straight out in front of you.
Extend your arms forward for counterbalance.
Engage your core and maintain balance.
Lower down slowly on the standing leg, keeping the non-working leg off the floor.
Descend as low as possible, ideally until your hamstring rests on your calf, keeping the back straight.
Push through the heel of the standing foot to return to the starting position.
Maintain control throughout. Use assistance (TRX, holding onto support) if needed.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
description: A challenging single-leg squat requiring significant strength, balance, mobility, and control.

name: Shrimp Squat
instructions: Stand on one leg.
Bend the other knee and grab the foot or ankle of the non-standing leg with one or both hands behind your back.
Engage your core.
Slowly lower down by bending the standing knee, keeping your torso relatively upright.
Aim to touch the knee of the bent leg lightly to the floor behind you.
Push through the standing foot to return to the starting position.
Maintain balance and control.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
description: A single-leg squat variation where the non-working leg's foot is held behind the back, challenging balance and quad strength.

name: Cossack Squat
instructions: Stand with feet much wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly out.
Shift your weight onto one leg (e.g., right), bending that knee and lowering your hips down towards the heel.
Keep the other leg (left) straight, with toes pointing up or forward.
Keep your chest up and torso as upright as possible.
Lower as deep as mobility allows.
Push off the bent leg to return to the center or shift directly to the other side.
Repeat, alternating sides.
Can hold KB or DB for counterbalance/load.
description: A deep lateral squat that improves hip, groin, and ankle mobility while strengthening the legs.

name: Glute Bridge (Bodyweight)
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor hip-width apart, close to your glutes.
Place arms by your sides, palms down.
Engage your core and squeeze your glutes.
Press through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees.
Hold the contraction at the top briefly.
Slowly lower your hips back to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental exercise lying on the back to activate and strengthen the glute muscles.

name: Weighted Glute Bridge
instructions: Lie on your back in a glute bridge starting position (knees bent, feet flat).
Place a barbell, dumbbell, or weight plate across your hips (use padding if needed).
Hold the weight steady with your hands.
Engage your core and glutes.
Drive through your heels to lift your hips and the weight towards the ceiling.
Form a straight line from shoulders to knees.
Squeeze your glutes hard at the top.
Lower hips back down under control.
Repeat.
description: A glute bridge performed with added weight across the hips for increased resistance.

name: Single-Leg Glute Bridge
instructions: Lie on your back in a glute bridge starting position.
Extend one leg straight out or keep the knee bent towards your chest.
Engage core and glutes.
Press through the heel of the foot on the floor to lift your hips off the ground.
Keep your hips level; avoid letting one side drop.
Lift until your body is in a straight line from shoulder to knee of the working leg.
Squeeze the glute of the working leg at the top.
Lower hips back down under control.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A glute bridge performed using only one leg, increasing the challenge and targeting each glute individually.

name: Hip Thrust (Barbell)
instructions: Sit on the floor with your upper back against a sturdy bench.
Place a padded barbell across your hips.
Position feet flat on the floor, knees bent, close enough so that knees are roughly over heels at the top.
Grip the barbell to keep it stable.
Drive through your heels, extending your hips to lift the barbell until your torso is parallel to the floor.
Keep your chin tucked and ribs down.
Squeeze your glutes powerfully at the top (full hip extension).
Lower the barbell back down under control.
Repeat.
description: A popular exercise for targeting the glutes, involving bridging the hips up with a barbell while the upper back is supported on a bench.

name: Dumbbell Hip Thrust
instructions: Set up as for a barbell hip thrust, with your upper back against a bench.
Place a dumbbell across your hips, holding it steady with your hands.
Position feet flat on the floor, knees bent.
Drive through your heels, extending your hips to lift the dumbbell.
Achieve full hip extension, squeezing glutes at the top.
Lower the dumbbell back down under control.
Repeat.
description: A hip thrust variation using a dumbbell placed across the hips for resistance.

name: Single-Leg Hip Thrust
instructions: Set up with your upper back against a bench, feet flat on the floor.
Lift one foot off the floor, extending the leg or keeping the knee bent.
Hold a dumbbell on the hip of the working leg if desired.
Drive through the heel of the grounded foot, extending the hip to lift your body.
Keep hips level throughout the movement.
Squeeze the glute of the working leg at the top.
Lower back down under control.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A challenging hip thrust performed on one leg, increasing glute activation and stability demands.

name: Banded Hip Thrust
instructions: Loop a resistance band around your thighs, just above the knees.
Set up for a hip thrust (bodyweight or weighted) with your upper back against a bench.
Perform the hip thrust motion, driving hips up.
Simultaneously, actively push your knees outwards against the band, especially at the top.
Maintain outward tension throughout the rep.
Lower back down under control.
Repeat.
description: A hip thrust with a resistance band around the thighs to add lateral resistance and enhance gluteus medius activation.

name: Machine Hip Thrust
instructions: Position yourself in a dedicated hip thrust machine according to its specific instructions.
Typically involves securing a padded belt or bar across the hips.
Place feet firmly on the platform.
Drive through your heels to extend your hips against the machine's resistance.
Achieve full hip extension and squeeze glutes at the top.
Lower the weight back down under control.
Repeat.
description: Performing a hip thrust using a specialized machine designed for the movement.

name: Smith Machine Hip Thrust
instructions: Position a bench perpendicular to a Smith machine.
Lie with your upper back on the bench and position the Smith machine bar across your hips (use padding).
Place feet flat on the floor, knees bent.
Unlatch the bar.
Drive through your heels to extend your hips, lifting the bar along its fixed path.
Squeeze glutes at the top.
Lower the bar back down under control.
Repeat.
description: Using the guided path of a Smith machine to perform hip thrusts.

name: Glute Kickback
instructions: Attach an ankle strap to a low cable pulley. Secure the strap around one ankle.
Face the machine, standing slightly back for tension. Hold onto the machine for support.
Keeping your knee slightly bent and core engaged, drive your leg straight back, focusing on squeezing the glute of the working leg.
Avoid arching your lower back; keep the movement controlled and focused on hip extension.
Return the leg slowly to the starting position.
Complete reps on one side before switching. Can also be done on specific kickback machines.
description: An isolation exercise targeting the glutes by extending the leg backward against resistance from a cable or machine.

name: Romanian Deadlift (RDL)
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip just outside your thighs.
Maintain a slight bend in your knees throughout the movement.
Keeping your back straight and chest up, hinge at your hips, pushing them backward.
Lower the barbell by sliding it down your thighs, keeping it close to your body.
Lower until you feel a strong stretch in your hamstrings or your back starts to round.
Drive your hips forward to return to the starting position, squeezing your glutes at the top.
Repeat.
description: A hip-hinge exercise focusing on the hamstrings and glutes, involving lowering a weight with minimal knee bend.

name: Dumbbell RDL
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand in front of your thighs, palms facing your body.
Maintain a slight bend in your knees.
Keeping your back straight, hinge at your hips, pushing them back.
Lower the dumbbells towards the floor, keeping them close to your legs.
Feel the stretch in your hamstrings.
Drive hips forward to return to standing, squeezing glutes.
Repeat.
description: A Romanian Deadlift variation performed holding dumbbells.

name: Kettlebell RDL
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding one or two kettlebells in front of your thighs.
Maintain a slight bend in your knees.
Keeping your back straight, hinge at your hips, pushing them back.
Lower the kettlebell(s) towards the floor, keeping them close to your legs.
Feel the stretch in your hamstrings.
Drive hips forward to return to standing, squeezing glutes.
Repeat.
description: A Romanian Deadlift variation using one or two kettlebells.

name: Single-Leg RDL
instructions: Stand on one leg with a slight bend in the knee. Hold a dumbbell or kettlebell in the opposite hand (or one in each hand/bodyweight).
Keeping your back straight, hinge at the hip of the standing leg.
Lower the weight(s) towards the floor as your non-standing leg extends straight back behind you for counterbalance.
Keep hips square to the floor.
Lower until you feel a stretch in the hamstring of the standing leg or torso is parallel to floor.
Return to the starting position by driving the hip forward.
Maintain balance throughout.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
description: A unilateral RDL requiring significant balance and stability, targeting the hamstring and glute of the standing leg.

name: Staggered Stance RDL
instructions: Hold a barbell or dumbbells like a standard RDL.
Stand with one foot slightly behind the other, with the back foot resting lightly on the ball of the foot (like a kickstand).
Most of your weight should be on the front foot.
Keeping the front knee slightly bent and back straight, hinge at the hips, pushing them back.
Lower the weight, feeling the stretch primarily in the hamstring of the front leg.
Drive the front hip forward to return to the start.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
description: An RDL variation performed with one foot slightly back for support, focusing the load on the front leg while aiding balance.

name: Good Morning
instructions: Place a barbell across your upper back, similar to a high bar squat position.
Stand with feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent.
Keeping your back straight and core braced, hinge at your hips, pushing them backward.
Lower your torso towards parallel with the floor.
Keep the slight bend in your knees constant.
Feel the stretch in your hamstrings.
Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.
Use light weight initially; focus on form.
Repeat.
description: A hip-hinge exercise with the barbell on the back, targeting the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back.

name: Seated Good Morning
instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a barbell across your upper back.
Plant your feet firmly on the floor.
Keeping your back straight and core braced, slowly hinge forward at the hips.
Lower your torso towards your lap, maintaining the natural arch in your lower back.
Go as low as possible while maintaining a flat back.
Use your lower back and hamstrings to return to the upright seated position.
Requires caution and light weight.
Repeat.
description: A variation of the Good Morning performed seated, strongly emphasizing the spinal erectors.

name: Banded Good Morning
instructions: Stand on one end of a resistance band with feet hip-width apart.
Loop the other end of the band over your head and rest it across your upper back/neck.
Maintain a slight bend in your knees.
Keeping your back straight, hinge at your hips, pushing them back against the band's resistance.
Lower your torso forward.
Drive hips forward against the band to return to standing, squeezing glutes.
Repeat.
description: A Good Morning variation using a resistance band looped around the neck and under the feet.

name: Conventional Deadlift
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, shins close to the barbell.
Hinge at the hips and bend knees to grip the bar just outside your legs (mixed or double overhand grip).
Keep back straight, chest up, shoulders slightly over the bar.
Engage lats, brace core.
Initiate the lift by driving through your feet, extending knees and hips simultaneously.
Keep the bar close to your body.
Stand tall, pulling shoulders back slightly at the top (full lockout).
Lower the bar under control by reversing the motion (hinge hips back, then bend knees).
Repeat.
description: A fundamental compound exercise involving lifting a barbell from the floor with a hip-width stance, working numerous muscle groups.

name: Sumo Deadlift
instructions: Stand with a very wide stance, toes pointing outwards, shins close to the barbell.
Hinge at hips and bend knees to grip the bar inside your legs (narrower grip than conventional).
Keep back straight, chest up, hips low, torso more upright than conventional.
Engage lats, brace core.
Initiate lift by driving feet outwards and extending knees and hips.
Keep the bar close.
Stand tall, locking out hips and knees.
Lower the bar under control by reversing the motion.
Repeat.
description: A deadlift variation using a wide stance and grip inside the legs, emphasizing glutes, quads, and adductors more.

name: Trap Bar Deadlift
instructions: Stand inside the trap bar, feet hip-width apart.
Hinge at hips and bend knees to grip the handles (use high or low handles).
Keep back straight, chest up.
Brace core.
Drive through your feet, extending knees and hips simultaneously.
The handles allow the weight to be centered, often allowing a more upright torso.
Stand tall, locking out.
Lower the bar under control by reversing the motion.
Repeat.
description: A deadlift variation using a hexagonal (trap) bar, allowing a more neutral grip and often feeling like a hybrid between a squat and deadlift.

name: Dumbbell Deadlift
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, dumbbells placed outside your feet.
Hinge at hips and bend knees to grip the dumbbells, palms facing your body.
Keep back straight, chest up.
Brace core.
Drive through your feet, extending knees and hips, lifting the dumbbells.
Keep dumbbells close to your body/sides.
Stand tall.
Lower the dumbbells under control by reversing the motion.
Repeat.
description: A deadlift movement pattern performed using dumbbells instead of a barbell.

name: Kettlebell Deadlift
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, with one or two kettlebells between your feet.
Hinge at hips and bend knees to grip the kettlebell(s).
Keep back straight, chest up.
Brace core.
Drive through your feet, extending knees and hips, lifting the kettlebell(s).
Keep the weight close.
Stand tall.
Lower the kettlebell(s) under control by reversing the motion.
Repeat.
description: Performing a deadlift movement using one or two kettlebells.

name: Deficit Deadlift
instructions: Stand on a sturdy elevated platform or weight plates (e.g., 1-4 inches high).
Position the barbell on the floor in front of the platform.
Set up for a conventional or sumo deadlift, but starting from a deeper position due to the deficit.
Grip the bar.
Maintain a tight back and core brace.
Initiate the lift, driving strongly through the feet.
Complete the deadlift lockout.
Lower under control.
Requires good mobility and control.
Repeat.
description: A deadlift performed while standing on an elevated surface, increasing the range of motion and difficulty off the floor.

name: Block/Rack Pull
instructions: Set a barbell on blocks or safety pins in a rack at a desired height (typically below or just above the knee).
Stand facing the bar, feet hip-width apart.
Hinge at hips and bend knees slightly to grip the bar.
Your starting position will be higher than a standard deadlift.
Keep back straight, chest up, brace core.
Drive through feet, extending hips and knees to lift the bar.
Focus on pulling with your back and glutes to finish the lockout.
Lower the bar back to the blocks/pins under control.
Repeat.
description: A deadlift variation performed with the bar elevated on blocks or rack pins, shortening the range of motion to focus on lockout strength and upper back.

name: Stiff-Legged Deadlift
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells like an RDL.
Keep your legs almost straight, with only a very slight bend in the knees (stiffer than RDL).
Maintain a flat back.
Hinge primarily at the hips, lowering the weight towards the floor.
Lower as far as hamstring flexibility allows while keeping the back straight.
The bar may touch the floor or hover just above it.
Return to the starting position by contracting hamstrings and glutes.
Avoid rounding the lower back.
Repeat.
