description: A deadlift variation emphasizing the hamstrings, performed with minimal knee bend throughout the movement.

name: Snatch Grip Deadlift
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, shins close to the bar.
Take a wide (snatch) grip on the barbell.
Hinge at hips and bend knees, keeping back straight, chest up.
Your starting position will be lower than a conventional deadlift due to the wide grip.
Engage lats strongly, brace core.
Drive through feet, extending hips and knees.
Keep the bar close.
Stand tall, locking out.
Lower under control.
Repeat.
description: A deadlift performed with a wide snatch grip, increasing the range of motion and demand on the back muscles.

name: Leg Press
instructions: Sit in the leg press machine, placing your back and head comfortably against the padded support.
Place feet on the platform, typically shoulder-width apart (adjust for muscle emphasis: higher=glutes/hams, lower=quads, wider=adductors).
Ensure your lower back remains in contact with the seat pad.
Release the safety bars.
Lower the platform by bending your knees until they form roughly a 90-degree angle or as low as comfortable without lifting hips.
Push the platform back up by extending your knees, driving through your heels/midfoot.
Do not lock out knees completely at the top.
Repeat.
description: A machine-based exercise for pressing weight away using the legs, targeting quads, glutes, and hamstrings based on foot placement.

name: Single-Leg Leg Press
instructions: Sit in the leg press machine.
Place one foot firmly on the platform, positioned towards the center.
Keep the non-working foot off the platform or resting lightly.
Release the safety bars.
Lower the platform by bending the knee of the working leg.
Maintain control and keep your hips stable on the seat.
Push the platform back up using the working leg.
Do not lock out the knee.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing the leg press using one leg at a time to address imbalances and increase unilateral strength.

name: Hack Squat (Machine)
instructions: Position yourself in the hack squat machine, shoulders under the pads, back flat against the back pad.
Place feet shoulder-width apart on the platform (lower placement emphasizes quads more).
Release the safety handles.
Lower the weight by bending your knees, keeping your back against the pad.
Descend until thighs are parallel to the platform or lower, if comfortable.
Push through your heels/midfoot to extend your knees and return to the starting position.
Avoid locking out knees.
Repeat.
description: A machine squat variation where the body moves along a fixed angle, heavily targeting the quadriceps.

name: Reverse Hack Squat
instructions: Face towards the hack squat machine, placing your chest and stomach against the back pad.
Position shoulders under the pads.
Place feet shoulder-width apart on the platform.
Release safety handles.
Lower the weight by bending knees and hinging slightly at the hips, maintaining contact with the pad.
Focus on pushing hips back.
Drive through heels/midfoot, extending hips and knees to return to the start.
Squeeze glutes at the top.
Repeat.
description: Performing a squat facing into the hack squat machine, shifting emphasis towards the glutes and hamstrings.

name: V-Squat Machine
instructions: Position yourself in the V-squat machine, shoulders under pads, back against the support.
Place feet shoulder-width apart on the platform.
The machine typically follows an arc path rather than a straight linear path.
Release safety handles.
Lower down by bending knees and hips, following the machine's movement path.
Keep back supported.
Push through feet to return to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A machine squat variation that follows a specific V-shaped or arcing path, targeting the quads and glutes.

name: Pendulum Squat
instructions: Position yourself in the pendulum squat machine, back against the pad, shoulders under supports.
Place feet on the platform.
The weight moves in a pendulum-like arc.
Release safety mechanism.
Lower down by bending knees, allowing the machine's arc to guide the movement.
Descend deeply.
Push through feet to return to the start, extending knees and hips.
Repeat.
description: A machine squat known for its unique pendulum arc, often allowing deep squats with reduced stress on knees/back for some users.

name: Leg Extension
instructions: Sit in the leg extension machine with your back flat against the pad.
Adjust the shin pad so it rests comfortably on your lower shins, just above the ankles.
Align your knees with the machine's pivot point.
Hold the handles for stability.
Extend your legs upwards by contracting your quadriceps, until legs are straight but not hyperextended.
Pause briefly at the top, squeezing the quads.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position under control.
Repeat.
description: An isolation exercise performed on a machine to target the quadriceps muscles by extending the knee.

name: Single-Leg Extension
instructions: Sit in the leg extension machine.
Position one leg under the shin pad as normal.
Keep the other leg out of the way.
Extend the working leg upwards by contracting the quadriceps.
Squeeze at the top.
Lower the weight back down under control.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing the leg extension exercise one leg at a time for unilateral focus.

name: Lying Leg Curl
instructions: Lie face down on the lying leg curl machine.
Align your knees just off the edge of the bench, near the machine's pivot point.
Position the padded lever comfortably on the back of your lower legs/ankles.
Hold onto the handles for stability.
Curl your legs upwards towards your glutes by contracting your hamstrings.
Keep your hips pressed firmly into the bench; avoid lifting them.
Squeeze hamstrings at the peak contraction.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position under control.
Repeat.
description: An isolation exercise for the hamstrings performed lying prone on a machine, curling the heels towards the glutes.

name: Seated Leg Curl
instructions: Sit in the seated leg curl machine, back flat against the pad.
Place your legs over the top padded lever and hook your ankles behind the lower padded lever.
Adjust the thigh pad to secure your legs firmly.
Align knees with the machine's pivot point.
Hold the handles.
Curl your legs downwards by contracting your hamstrings.
Pull the lever as far down as comfortable.
Squeeze hamstrings at the bottom.
Slowly return the weight to the starting position under control.
Repeat.
description: An isolation exercise for the hamstrings performed seated, curling a padded lever down with the ankles.

name: Standing Leg Curl
instructions: Stand facing the standing leg curl machine (or cable station with ankle strap).
Place one leg in front of the padded lever (or attach strap).
Support your upper body by holding the handles or machine frame.
Keep your standing leg slightly bent and core engaged.
Curl the working leg upwards towards your glutes by contracting the hamstring.
Keep your thigh stable; movement should come from the knee joint.
Squeeze hamstring at the top.
Lower the weight back down under control.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A hamstring curl performed standing, usually one leg at a time, using a machine or cable.

name: Single-Leg Lying Leg Curl
instructions: Lie face down on the lying leg curl machine.
Position one leg under the padded lever.
Keep the other leg straight or bent out of the way.
Curl the working leg up towards your glute, keeping hips down.
Squeeze hamstring at the top.
Lower under control.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing the lying leg curl one leg at a time.

name: Single-Leg Seated Leg Curl
instructions: Sit in the seated leg curl machine.
Position one ankle behind the lower padded lever.
Secure the thigh pad over the working leg.
Keep the other leg out of the way.
Curl the working leg downwards, contracting the hamstring.
Squeeze at the bottom.
Return under control.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing the seated leg curl one leg at a time.

name: Glute Ham Raise (GHR)
instructions: Adjust the Glute Ham Raise machine so your knees are on the pad and feet are secured against the foot plate.
Start with your torso upright.
Maintain a straight line from knees to head.
Lower your torso forward by pivoting at the knees, controlling the descent with your hamstrings.
Go until your torso is parallel to the floor or slightly below.
Pull yourself back up using primarily your hamstrings and glutes.
Minimize pushing off with toes initially.
Repeat.
description: A challenging exercise performed on a GHR apparatus, targeting hamstrings, glutes, and lower back by pivoting at the knee.

name: Nordic Hamstring Curl
instructions: Kneel on a padded surface with ankles secured (by a partner holding them down, or under a sturdy object/machine).
Keep your body in a straight line from knees to head, core braced.
Slowly lower your torso towards the floor, controlling the movement with your hamstrings (eccentric focus).
Lower as far as you can control.
Gently push off the floor with your hands to help initiate the upward movement (concentric), or pull back up using hamstrings if strong enough.
Focus on the slow, controlled lowering phase.
Repeat.
description: A highly effective but difficult hamstring exercise focusing on the eccentric (lowering) phase, requiring anchored ankles.

name: Reverse Nordic Curl
instructions: Kneel on a padded surface with tops of feet flat on the floor (or toes tucked).
Keep body in a straight line from knees to head, glutes squeezed, core braced.
Slowly lean your torso backward, pivoting only at the knees.
Maintain the straight line; do not hinge at the hips.
Feel the stretch/load in your quadriceps.
Lean back as far as you can control.
Return to the starting position by contracting your quads.
Focus on the controlled eccentric (leaning back) phase.
Repeat.
description: An exercise focusing on eccentrically loading the quadriceps by leaning backward from a kneeling position.

name: Standing Calf Raise
instructions: Use a standing calf raise machine, place barbell on back, hold dumbbells, or use Smith machine.
Stand with the balls of your feet on the edge of the platform/step, heels hanging off.
Keep legs straight (slight knee bend is ok).
Lower your heels as far as comfortable to stretch the calves.
Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible, contracting the calves.
Pause at the top.
Slowly lower back down.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental exercise for the calf muscles (primarily gastrocnemius) performed standing with resistance.

name: Seated Calf Raise
instructions: Sit in a seated calf raise machine, placing the balls of your feet on the platform, heels hanging off.
Position the knee pad securely on your lower thighs, just above the knees.
Release the safety lever.
Lower your heels as far as comfortable.
Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible, contracting the calves.
Pause at the top.
Slowly lower back down.
Repeat.
description: A calf exercise performed seated with knees bent, primarily targeting the deeper soleus muscle.

name: Leg Press Calf Raise
instructions: Sit in a leg press machine.
Place the balls of your feet near the bottom edge of the platform, keeping legs mostly straight (soft knees).
Release safety bars (use lighter weight than leg press).
Let your heels drop by flexing your ankles downwards (dorsiflexion), stretching the calves.
Push through the balls of your feet to extend your ankles (plantarflexion), lifting the weight.
Contract calves at the top.
Slowly lower back down.
Repeat.
description: Performing calf raises using the leg press machine platform for resistance.

name: Donkey Calf Raise
instructions: Using a donkey calf raise machine (or bending over with support, potentially having a partner sit on your lower back).
Place the balls of your feet on the platform/step.
Lean forward, supporting your upper body on pads or hands.
The resistance pad rests on your lower back/hips.
Lower your heels to stretch the calves.
Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels high.
Contract calves at the top.
Slowly lower.
Repeat.
description: A calf raise variation performed hinged at the hips, believed to provide a greater stretch to the gastrocnemius.

name: Single-Leg Calf Raise
instructions: Stand on one leg, optionally holding a dumbbell in the same side hand for weight.
Place the ball of the standing foot on the edge of a step or platform, heel hanging off.
Use the other hand for balance support if needed.
Lower the heel as far as comfortable.
Push through the ball of the foot to raise the heel as high as possible.
Pause and contract the calf.
Lower slowly.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing calf raises on one leg at a time for increased intensity and focus.

name: Tibialis Raise
instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, feet about 1-2 feet away from the wall.
Keep legs relatively straight.
Lift the forefoot and toes of both feet off the ground towards your shins, keeping heels planted.
Feel the contraction in the muscle on the front of your shin (tibialis anterior).
Hold briefly.
Slowly lower your forefoot back to the ground.
Can also be done seated, or using bands/machines.
Repeat.
description: An exercise targeting the muscle on the front of the shin (tibialis anterior) by lifting the toes/forefoot.

name: Hip Abduction Machine
instructions: Sit in the hip abduction machine, placing the outside of your thighs/knees against the pads.
Keep your back flat against the seat.
Push your legs outwards against the pads, contracting your outer hip muscles.
Move through a comfortable range of motion.
Control the movement as you slowly bring your legs back to the starting position.
Avoid using momentum.
Repeat.
description: A machine exercise isolating the hip abductor muscles (outer hips/glutes) by pushing the legs outwards.

name: Seated Banded Hip Abduction
instructions: Sit on a bench or chair with feet flat on the floor, knees bent at 90 degrees.
Place a looped resistance band around both thighs, just above the knees.
Keep feet stationary.
Push your knees outwards against the resistance of the band.
Focus on using your outer hip muscles.
Hold the abducted position briefly.
Slowly return knees to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A hip abduction exercise performed seated using a resistance band around the thighs.

name: Standing Cable Hip Abduction
instructions: Attach an ankle strap to a low cable pulley. Secure the strap to the ankle furthest from the machine.
Stand sideways to the machine, holding onto it for support.
Keep your standing leg slightly bent and core engaged.
Move the strapped leg straight out to the side, away from your body, against the cable resistance.
Keep your torso upright and avoid leaning excessively.
Control the movement as you return the leg to the starting position.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Using a cable machine and ankle strap to perform hip abduction while standing.

name: Side Lying Hip Abduction
instructions: Lie on your side, legs straight and stacked.
Support your head with your bottom arm.
Keep your core engaged and hips stable (prevent rolling forward or back).
Keeping your top leg straight and foot neutral (or slightly pointed down), lift the leg upwards towards the ceiling.
Focus on initiating from the outer hip.
Lift as high as you can without tilting your pelvis.
Slowly lower the leg back down.
Can add ankle weight for resistance.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A bodyweight exercise targeting the hip abductors by lifting the top leg while lying on your side.

name: Clamshells
instructions: Lie on your side with knees bent approximately 90 degrees, feet together, hips stacked.
Keep feet touching each other.
Engage core to stabilize pelvis.
Lift your top knee upwards, rotating at the hip, while keeping feet together.
Open the 'clamshell' as far as possible without rolling your hips back.
Focus on using the outer glute muscle.
Slowly lower the top knee back down.
Can add band around thighs for resistance.
Complete reps, then switch sides.
Repeat.
description: A hip external rotation exercise targeting the gluteus medius, performed lying on the side with bent knees.

name: Fire Hydrants
instructions: Start on hands and knees, hands under shoulders, knees under hips.
Keep back flat, core engaged.
Maintaining the 90-degree bend in your knee, lift one leg out to the side, away from your body.
Keep pelvis stable; minimize tilting.
Lift the knee as high as possible without rotation.
Hold briefly.
Slowly lower the knee back to the start.
Can add band around thighs for resistance.
Complete reps, then switch sides.
Repeat.
description: A hip abduction and external rotation exercise performed on all fours, lifting the bent knee out to the side.

name: Hip Adduction Machine
instructions: Sit in the hip adduction machine, placing the inside of your thighs/knees against the pads.
Adjust the starting position (width) as needed.
Keep your back flat against the seat.
Squeeze your legs together against the pads by contracting your inner thigh muscles.
Move through a comfortable range of motion.
Control the movement as the pads return to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A machine exercise isolating the inner thigh muscles (adductors) by squeezing the legs together.

name: Standing Cable Hip Adduction
instructions: Attach an ankle strap to a low cable pulley. Secure the strap to the ankle closest to the machine.
Stand sideways to the machine, holding onto it for support.
Keep standing leg slightly bent, core engaged.
Move the strapped leg across the front of your body, pulling against the cable resistance.
Focus on contracting the inner thigh of the moving leg.
Keep torso stable.
Control the movement as you return the leg to the starting position.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Using a cable machine and ankle strap to perform hip adduction (moving leg inward across body) while standing.

name: Copenhagen Plank
instructions: Position yourself in a side plank setup next to a bench or sturdy elevated surface.
Place your top leg (shin or foot) onto the bench.
Your bottom arm (forearm or hand) supports your upper body off the floor.
Lift your hips off the floor, forming a straight line.
Your bottom leg can be bent underneath you (easier) or lifted off the floor to meet the top leg (harder).
Hold the position, focusing on the isometric contraction in the adductor of the top leg and obliques.
Maintain hip height.
Hold for time, then switch sides.
description: An advanced isometric exercise targeting the adductors (inner thigh) and obliques, involving a side plank with the top leg elevated.

name: Sissy Squat
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, optionally holding onto a support for balance.
Rise up onto the balls of your feet.
Keeping a straight line from knees to shoulders (push hips forward), lean your torso backward while simultaneously bending your knees forward towards the floor.
Lower as far as comfortable, feeling an intense stretch/contraction in the quads.
Return to the starting position by contracting your quads.
Requires good knee health and control. Start with limited range of motion.
Repeat.
description: A challenging bodyweight exercise focusing on the quads by leaning back while keeping hips extended, placing significant stress on the knee joint.

name: Wall Sit
instructions: Stand with your back against a wall.
Walk your feet forward away from the wall.
Slide your back down the wall until your knees are bent at a 90-degree angle and thighs are parallel to the floor.
Ensure your knees are directly above your ankles.
Keep your back flat against the wall.
Engage your core.
Hold this isometric position for the desired duration.
description: An isometric exercise holding a squat position against a wall, primarily building endurance in the quadriceps.

name: Wall Sit with Calf Raise
instructions: Assume the standard wall sit position (back against wall, thighs parallel to floor).
While holding the wall sit, slowly raise both heels off the floor, pushing through the balls of your feet.
Hold the calf raise briefly.
Slowly lower your heels back to the floor.
Repeat the calf raise motion while maintaining the wall sit.
Continue for reps or time.
description: Combining a wall sit with calf raises to challenge both quad endurance and calf strength simultaneously.

name: Sumo Squat
instructions: Stand with feet significantly wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointed outwards (e.g., 45 degrees).
Keep your chest up and core engaged. (Optionally hold DB or KB).
Lower your hips straight down by bending your knees.
Keep knees tracking in line with toes.
Maintain an upright torso.
Lower until thighs are parallel to the ground or as deep as comfortable.
Push through your feet to return to the starting position.
Squeeze glutes at the top.
Repeat.
description: A squat variation with a wide stance and outward-pointed toes, emphasizing the inner thighs (adductors) and glutes.

name: Kettlebell Swing
instructions: Stand with feet slightly wider than hip-width, kettlebell on the floor slightly in front.
Hinge at hips, keeping back flat, grip KB with both hands.
Hike the KB back between your legs.
Explosively drive hips forward, squeezing glutes, allowing the KB to swing up to chest height.
Arms remain relatively relaxed; power comes from hips.
Let the KB swing back down between legs, controlling it with hip hinge.
Maintain flat back throughout.
Repeat in a fluid rhythm.
description: A dynamic, explosive hip-hinge exercise using a kettlebell, primarily targeting the posterior chain for power development.

name: Sled Push
instructions: Load a sled with appropriate weight.
Grip the handles firmly (high or low position).
Lean forward with arms extended or bent.
Keep your core braced and back straight.
Drive the sled forward by powerfully pushing with your legs.
Take strong, deliberate steps.
Maintain momentum.
Push for the desired distance or time.
description: Pushing a weighted sled across the floor, providing excellent conditioning and leg strength work.

name: Sled Pull
instructions: Attach straps or ropes to a weighted sled.
Hold the straps.
Either face away from the sled and walk forward (pulling behind you) or face the sled and walk backward (pulling towards you).
Maintain an athletic stance, core braced.
Use your legs and back to pull the sled.
Take controlled steps.
Pull for the desired distance or time.
description: Pulling a weighted sled using straps, working the posterior chain and back muscles.

name: Tire Flip
instructions: Approach a large tire.
Get into a low squat/deadlift position, chest up, back straight.
Wedge your fingers under the edge of the tire.
Initiate the lift by driving powerfully with your legs and hips.
As the tire lifts, transition your hands to push.
Drive the tire upward and forward using legs and upper body.
Push it over completely.
Requires proper technique to avoid injury. Use appropriate tire size.
Repeat for desired reps or distance.
description: A full-body power exercise involving flipping a large tire end over end.

name: Prowler Push
instructions: Load a prowler sled with weight.
Grip the handles (high or low).
Lean into the prowler, keeping core tight and back straight.
Drive forward using powerful leg strides.
Maintain constant pressure.
Push for the desired distance or time.
description: Similar to a sled push, using a prowler sled, for strength and conditioning.

name: Step-Over
instructions: Set up low hurdles or boxes in a line.
Stand beside the first hurdle.
Step laterally over the hurdle, lifting your lead knee high.
Bring the trailing leg over.
Continue stepping over each hurdle down the line.
Can also be done stepping forward over hurdles.
Focus on controlled movement and hip mobility.
Repeat in both directions.
description: A mobility drill involving stepping over low obstacles to improve hip range of motion and coordination.

name: Lateral Box Shuffle
instructions: Stand sideways next to a low box or step.
Assume an athletic stance (knees bent, core engaged).
Shuffle laterally towards the box.
Quickly tap the top of the box with the lead foot.
Shuffle back to the starting position.
Alternatively, step fully onto and over the box laterally.
Maintain a low stance and quick feet.
Repeat for time or reps, then switch lead side.
description: An agility drill involving shuffling laterally and interacting with a box, improving side-to-side movement and hip work.

name: Belt Squat Machine
instructions: Step onto the platform of the belt squat machine.
Secure the belt firmly around your hips.
Attach the belt to the machine's loading mechanism.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Hold onto the support handles.
Release the weight.
Squat down by bending knees and hips, keeping torso upright.
The weight is loaded directly onto the hips, reducing spinal load.
Squat to desired depth.
Push through feet to return to standing.
Repeat.
description: A squat performed on a specialized machine where weight is loaded via a belt around the hips, minimizing spinal compression.

name: Reverse Hyperextension
instructions: Position yourself face down on a reverse hyperextension machine, with hips at the edge of the pad and torso supported.
Grip the handles firmly.
Your legs should hang down freely (strap weight to ankles or secure between feet if machine allows).
Keeping legs straight or slightly bent, lift them upwards by contracting your glutes and hamstrings.
Lift until legs are roughly in line with your torso.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back.
Lower legs back down under control.
Repeat.
description: An exercise targeting the posterior chain by lifting the legs while the torso remains stationary, often performed on a specific machine.

name: 45-Degree Hyperextension (Glute Focus)
instructions: Position yourself on a 45-degree hyperextension bench, pads supporting upper thighs.
Anchor your ankles under the foot pads.
Allow your torso to hang down.
To focus on glutes: Slightly round your upper back and maintain this position.
Initiate the movement by squeezing your glutes to lift your torso until it's in line with your legs.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back.
Focus on driving hips into the pad.
Lower back down slowly.
Repeat.
description: Using a 45-degree hyperextension bench to primarily target the glutes and hamstrings by extending the hips.

name: Jefferson Squat
instructions: Place a barbell on the floor.
Stand straddling the center of the barbell, feet wider than shoulder-width, one foot slightly ahead of the other.
Toes pointed outwards.
Squat down, keeping torso upright.
Grip the bar with a mixed grip (one palm forward, one back) between your legs.
Ensure grip is centered.
Keeping back straight and core braced, stand up by driving through your legs.
The bar lifts between your legs.
Lower under control back to the floor.
Repeat. Alternate foot forward position each set if desired.
description: An unconventional squat/deadlift hybrid where the lifter straddles the barbell and lifts it between their legs.

name: Jefferson Curl
instructions: Stand tall on a box or elevated surface to allow full range of motion, holding a light kettlebell or dumbbell.
Tuck your chin to your chest.
Slowly round your spine downwards, one vertebra at a time, starting from the neck.
Keep legs straight (slight knee bend ok if needed).
Lower the weight towards the floor, focusing on spinal flexion and hamstring stretch.
Go as low as comfortable.
Slowly reverse the movement, stacking your spine back up vertebra by vertebra, head coming up last.
Use very light weight and extreme caution. Focus on control and stretch, not load.
Repeat.
description: A mobility exercise involving controlled spinal flexion while holding a light weight, aiming to stretch hamstrings and decompress spine. Requires caution.

name: Seated Calf Stretch
instructions: Sit on the floor with one leg extended straight.
Bend the other knee and place the foot flat on the floor.
Loop a towel or band around the ball of the foot of the extended leg.
Gently pull the towel/band towards you, flexing your ankle (dorsiflexion).
Keep the leg straight.
Feel the stretch in the calf.
Hold for desired duration.
Alternatively, sit with knees bent, feet flat, and lean forward pushing knees over toes.
Switch legs.
description: A static stretch for the calf muscles, particularly the soleus when the knee is bent.

name: Standing Hamstring Stretch
instructions: Stand tall.
Place one heel on a slightly elevated surface (like a low step) or keep it on the floor.
Keep the stretching leg straight or with a very slight bend.
Keep the standing leg slightly bent.
Maintaining a flat back, hinge at your hips, leaning your torso forward over the straight leg.
Feel the stretch in the back of the thigh.
Avoid rounding your back; focus on the hip hinge.
Hold for desired duration.
Switch legs.
description: A common static stretch targeting the hamstring muscles.

name: Standing Quad Stretch
instructions: Stand tall, holding onto a support for balance if needed.
Bend one knee and bring the heel towards your glute.
Grab your ankle or foot with the same-side hand.
Gently pull the heel closer to your glute.
Keep knees close together and torso upright.
Tuck your tailbone slightly to increase stretch on hip flexor.
Feel the stretch in the front of your thigh.
Hold for desired duration.
Switch legs.
description: A static stretch for the quadriceps muscles performed while standing.

name: Pigeon Pose
instructions: Start on hands and knees.
Bring your right knee forward towards your right wrist.
Angle your right shin across the front of your mat/floor (degree of angle depends on flexibility).
Extend your left leg straight back behind you, top of the foot on the floor.
Keep hips square to the front.
Stay upright on your hands, or fold forward over your front leg for a deeper stretch.
Feel the stretch in the outer hip of the front leg.
Breathe deeply and hold.
Carefully come out and switch sides.
description: A yoga pose effectively stretching the external hip rotators (glutes, piriformis) and hip flexor of the back leg.

name: Frog Stretch
instructions: Start on hands and knees.
Widen your knees as far apart as comfortable, keeping insides of knees and shins on the floor.
Ensure your ankles are aligned behind your knees (forming 90-degree angles at knees and hips).
Flex your feet.
Lower down onto your forearms or stay on hands.
Gently push your hips backward towards your heels.
Feel the stretch in your inner thighs/groin.
Hold the position, breathing deeply.
Come out slowly and carefully.
description: A deep stretch for the inner thighs (adductors) and groin, performed from a kneeling position.

name: Butterfly Stretch
instructions: Sit upright on the floor.
Bring the soles of your feet together in front of you.
Let your knees drop outwards towards the floor.
Hold onto your ankles or feet.
Sit tall, keeping your back straight.
To deepen the stretch, gently press your knees down with your elbows or lean your torso forward with a flat back.
Feel the stretch in your inner thighs.
Hold for desired duration.
description: A seated stretch targeting the inner thighs (adductors) by bringing the soles of the feet together.

name: Kneeling Hip Flexor Stretch
instructions: Kneel on one knee (use padding if needed).
Place the other foot flat on the floor in front, knee bent at 90 degrees.
Keep torso upright, core engaged.
Tuck your tailbone under slightly (posterior pelvic tilt).
Gently shift your hips forward without leaning your torso forward.
Feel the stretch in the front of the hip of the kneeling leg.
Hold for desired duration. Can raise arm on kneeling side overhead for deeper stretch.
Switch legs.
description: A static stretch performed kneeling to target the hip flexor muscles.

name: Couch Stretch
instructions: Kneel facing away from a wall or couch.
Place the top of one foot against the wall/couch, with the knee resting on the floor close to the wall.
Step the other foot forward into a lunge position.
Keep your torso upright (this may be challenging).
Tuck your tailbone under and try to bring your torso fully upright.
Feel an intense stretch in the hip flexor and quad of the back leg.
Hold for desired duration, breathing deeply.
Carefully come out and switch sides.
description: An intense stretch targeting the quadriceps and hip flexors, performed with the back foot elevated against a surface.

name: Figure Four Stretch (Lying/Seated)
instructions: Lying: Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat.
Cross your right ankle over your left thigh, just above the knee.
Keep right foot flexed.
Reach through the gap and grasp the back of your left thigh (or front of left shin for deeper stretch).
Gently pull your left leg towards your chest.
Feel the stretch in your right glute/hip.
Hold. Release and switch sides.
Seated: Follow instructions from ID 74.
description: A stretch for the glutes and piriformis, performed lying on the back or seated, creating a 'figure four' shape with the legs.

name: Piriformis Stretch
instructions: There are various piriformis stretches; one common method is similar to the Figure Four stretch (lying or seated).
Another: Sit on the floor with both legs extended.
Bend your right knee and place your right foot flat on the floor outside your left knee.
Place your right hand on the floor behind you for support.
Place your left elbow on the outside of your right knee.
Gently twist your torso to the right, using your elbow to press against your knee.
Feel the stretch deep in the right glute/hip.
Hold. Release and switch sides.
description: Stretches specifically targeting the deep piriformis muscle in the hip, often used to alleviate sciatic-like symptoms.

name: Push-Up
instructions: Start in a high plank position with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, fingers pointing forward.
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels, engaging your core and glutes.
Lower your chest towards the floor by bending your elbows, keeping them at about a 45-degree angle from your body.
Lower until your chest is close to the ground or elbows reach 90 degrees.
Push through your palms to extend your elbows and return to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental bodyweight exercise targeting the chest, shoulders, and triceps.

name: Wide Grip Push-Up
instructions: Start in a high plank position with hands placed significantly wider than shoulder-width apart.
Keep your body straight, core engaged.
Lower your chest towards the floor by bending your elbows, allowing them to flare out more than a standard push-up.
Push back up to the starting position.
Focus on the outer chest muscles.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation with a wider hand placement, emphasizing the outer chest muscles.

name: Narrow Grip Push-Up
instructions: Start in a high plank position with hands placed closer than shoulder-width apart, under your chest.
Keep your body straight, core engaged.
Lower your chest towards the floor, keeping your elbows tucked close to your sides.
Push back up through your palms, focusing on triceps extension.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation with hands close together, shifting emphasis to the triceps.

name: Diamond Push-Up
instructions: Start in a high plank position.
Place your hands close together directly under your chest, forming a diamond shape with your index fingers and thumbs.
Keep your body straight, core engaged.
Lower your chest towards your hands, keeping elbows tucked in close to your body.
Push back up forcefully through your palms, fully extending the triceps.
Repeat.
description: An advanced close-grip push-up variation placing significant load on the triceps.

name: Incline Push-Up
instructions: Place your hands on an elevated surface (bench, box, wall) slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Position your feet back so your body forms a straight line from head to heels.
Lower your chest towards the elevated surface by bending your elbows.
Keep core engaged.
Push back up to the starting position.
The higher the surface, the easier the exercise.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation with hands elevated, reducing the overall resistance and emphasizing the lower chest.

name: Decline Push-Up
instructions: Place your feet on an elevated surface (bench, box).
Position your hands on the floor slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Form a straight line from head to heels.
Lower your chest towards the floor by bending your elbows.
Keep core engaged.
Push back up to the starting position.
The higher the elevation for feet, the harder the exercise.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation with feet elevated, increasing resistance and emphasizing the upper chest and shoulders.

name: Knee Push-Up
instructions: Start in a modified plank position on your hands and knees.
Walk your hands forward slightly and position them wider than shoulder-width.
Keep a straight line from your head to your knees, core engaged.
Lower your chest towards the floor by bending your elbows.
Push back up to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A modified push-up performed on the knees, reducing the load and making it easier for beginners.

name: Plyometric Push-Up
instructions: Start in a standard push-up position.
Lower your chest towards the floor.
Explosively push upwards with enough force for your hands to leave the ground.
Optional: Clap your hands together in mid-air.
Land softly back on your hands, absorbing the impact by bending elbows slightly.
Immediately lower into the next rep or reset.
Repeat.
description: An explosive push-up variation where the hands leave the ground, developing chest and triceps power.

name: Archer Push-Up
instructions: Start in a wide grip push-up position.
Shift your weight onto one side (e.g., right).
Lower your chest towards the floor over the hand on that side, bending the elbow.
Keep the opposite arm (left) relatively straight, extended out to the side.
Push back up, returning to the center or shifting directly to the other side.
Focus on the working side's chest and tricep.
Alternate sides.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation emphasizing one side at a time, shifting laterally towards one hand while keeping the other arm straighter.

name: Typewriter Push-Up
instructions: Start in a wide grip push-up position.
Lower your chest towards the floor.
At the bottom, keep your chest close to the ground and shift your body horizontally towards one hand.
Shift horizontally across towards the other hand.
Push back up from the center or from one side.
Maintain a low position during the lateral shift.
Repeat.
description: An advanced push-up involving lowering down and then shifting the body laterally side-to-side close to the floor.

name: Spiderman Push-Up
instructions: Start in a standard push-up position.
As you lower your chest towards the floor, simultaneously bring one knee (e.g., right) outwards towards the elbow on the same side.
Push back up to the starting position while returning the leg.
Alternate legs on each repetition.
Keep core engaged to control hip movement.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation that incorporates bringing one knee towards the same-side elbow during the descent, engaging the obliques.

name: Pike Push-Up
instructions: Start in a downward dog position: hands shoulder-width apart on the floor, hips high in the air, legs straight or slightly bent.
Keep hips elevated throughout.
Lower the top of your head towards the floor by bending your elbows.
Aim to form a triangle with your head and hands at the bottom.
Keep elbows tucked in slightly, not flared out wide.
Push back up through your hands, extending elbows and shoulders.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation performed with hips high, shifting emphasis to the shoulders and triceps.

name: Deficit Pike Push-Up
instructions: Place your hands on elevated surfaces (e.g., parallettes, yoga blocks, weight plates) shoulder-width apart.
Assume a pike position with feet on the floor, hips high.
The elevation allows for a greater range of motion.
Lower your head towards the floor between the elevated surfaces, going deeper than a standard pike push-up.
Push back up to the starting position.
Maintain high hip position.
Repeat.
description: A pike push-up performed with hands elevated, increasing the range of motion and difficulty.

name: Hindu Push-Up
instructions: Start in a downward dog / pike position (hips high).
Lower your head towards the floor as in a pike push-up, but then scoop your chest forward close to the ground, arching your back.
Continue the motion, pushing up into an upward dog position (hips low, chest up, arms straight).
Reverse the movement: push hips back up into the starting downward dog position.
The movement resembles diving under a fence.
Repeat.
description: A dynamic push-up variation involving a scooping motion, combining elements of pike and upward dog positions.

name: Pseudo Planche Push-Up
instructions: Start in a high plank position, but turn your hands so fingers point backward or outwards.
Lean your shoulders forward significantly, so they are well ahead of your wrists.
Keep your body straight and core intensely braced.
Lower down by bending your elbows, keeping them tucked close to your body.
Maintain the forward lean.
Push back up to the starting position.
The further the forward lean, the harder the exercise.
Repeat.
description: An advanced push-up requiring a strong forward lean, placing significant stress on shoulders, biceps, and wrists; a progression towards the planche.

name: Handstand Push-Up (Wall Assisted)
instructions: Kick up into a handstand position against a wall (either facing the wall or back to the wall).
Hands slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Brace your core tightly.
Slowly lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows.
Keep elbows tucked in slightly (not flared out wide).
Touch the top of your head lightly to the floor or a mat.
Press forcefully back up to the starting handstand position, fully extending elbows and shoulders.
Repeat.
description: A vertical pushing exercise performed in a handstand against a wall, heavily targeting the shoulders and triceps.

name: Freestanding Handstand Push-Up
instructions: Kick up into a freestanding handstand (away from any wall).
Find balance and stability.
Brace core intensely.
Slowly lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows, maintaining balance.
Control the descent.
Press forcefully back up to the handstand position, maintaining balance throughout.
Requires significant strength, balance, and control.
Repeat.
description: Performing a handstand push-up without wall assistance, requiring immense strength, skill, and balance.

name: Barbell Bench Press (Flat)
instructions: Lie flat on a bench, feet firmly planted on the floor.
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width, palms facing forward.
Arch your upper back slightly, retracting shoulder blades.
Unrack the bar and hold it directly above your chest, arms extended.
Lower the bar under control to your mid-chest.
Keep elbows tucked at roughly 45-75 degrees from your torso.
Lightly touch the chest.
Press the bar back up explosively to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A cornerstone strength exercise for the chest, shoulders, and triceps using a barbell on a flat bench.

name: Barbell Bench Press (Incline)
instructions: Set an adjustable bench to an incline angle (typically 30-45 degrees).
Lie on the bench, feet flat on the floor.
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Retract shoulder blades.
Unrack the bar and hold it above your upper chest.
Lower the bar under control to your upper chest.
Keep elbows slightly tucked.
Press the bar back up to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A bench press variation performed on an incline bench, emphasizing the upper portion of the chest and front shoulders.

name: Barbell Bench Press (Decline)
instructions: Set up on a decline bench, securing your legs under the pads.
Lie back on the bench.
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Retract shoulder blades.
Unrack the bar and hold it above your lower chest.
Lower the bar under control to your lower chest/sternum.
Keep elbows slightly tucked.
Press the bar back up to the starting position.
Use caution and potentially a spotter.
Repeat.
description: A bench press variation on a decline bench, targeting the lower portion of the pectoral muscles.

name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Flat)
instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding a dumbbell in each hand.
Start with dumbbells at chest level, palms facing each other or slightly forward.
Press the dumbbells upwards, extending your elbows.
Keep a slight arch in your upper back, shoulder blades retracted.
Lower the dumbbells under control back towards the sides of your chest, allowing a good stretch.
Keep elbows slightly tucked.
Repeat.
description: A bench press variation using dumbbells, allowing for a greater range of motion and requiring more stabilization.

name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Incline)
instructions: Set bench to an incline (30-45 degrees).
Lie on the bench holding dumbbells.
Start with dumbbells near your upper chest/shoulders.
Press the dumbbells upwards and slightly inwards.
Lower under control back to the starting position.
Focus on the upper chest.
Repeat.
description: Performing a dumbbell bench press on an incline bench to target the upper chest and shoulders.

name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Decline)
instructions: Set up on a decline bench, securing legs.
Lie back holding dumbbells.
Start with dumbbells near your lower chest.
Press the dumbbells upwards.
Lower under control, feeling a stretch in the lower chest.
Repeat.
description: Performing a dumbbell bench press on a decline bench to emphasize the lower chest fibers.

name: Smith Machine Bench Press
instructions: Position a flat, incline, or decline bench under the Smith machine bar.
Lie on the bench and position yourself so the bar aligns with the appropriate part of your chest.
Grip the bar with desired width.
Unlatch the bar.
Lower the bar under control towards your chest.
Press the bar back up along the fixed path.
Rerack the bar safely.
Repeat.
description: Performing a bench press (flat, incline, or decline) using the guided path of a Smith machine.

name: Close-Grip Barbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie flat on a bench.
Grip the barbell with a narrower grip, typically shoulder-width or slightly inside.
Unrack the bar.
Lower the bar towards your lower chest/upper abdomen, keeping your elbows tucked close to your sides.
Press the bar back up, focusing on extending the triceps.
Avoid excessive wrist strain.
Repeat.
description: A bench press variation with a narrow grip, shifting the emphasis strongly towards the triceps muscles.

name: Dumbbell Floor Press
instructions: Lie flat on the floor with knees bent and feet flat.
Hold a dumbbell in each hand.
Start with arms extended above your chest.
Lower the dumbbells towards the floor, keeping elbows tucked at about 45 degrees.
Lightly touch your upper arms/triceps to the floor.
Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.
The floor limits the range of motion, focusing on lockout.
Repeat.
description: A bench press variation performed lying on the floor with dumbbells, reducing range of motion and shoulder stress.

name: Barbell Floor Press
instructions: Lie flat on the floor, knees bent, feet flat.
Position a barbell over you (use low rack pins or roll into position carefully).
Grip the bar (standard or close grip).
Press the bar up.
Lower the bar until your upper arms/triceps touch the floor.
Pause briefly.
Press the bar back up forcefully.
Focuses on triceps and lockout strength.
Repeat.
description: A bench press variation performed lying on the floor with a barbell, limiting range of motion and emphasizing triceps.

name: Neutral Grip Dumbbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie on a flat or incline bench holding dumbbells.
Position the dumbbells with palms facing each other (neutral grip).
Lower the dumbbells towards the sides of your chest, keeping palms facing each other.
Keep elbows tucked closer to your body than a standard grip press.
Press the dumbbells back up.
Often easier on the shoulders.
Repeat.
description: A dumbbell bench press performed with palms facing each other, potentially reducing shoulder strain and engaging triceps more.

name: Alternating Dumbbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie on a flat or incline bench holding dumbbells, arms extended above chest.
Keep one arm stable and extended.
Lower the other dumbbell towards your chest.
Press that dumbbell back up.
Lower the opposite dumbbell while keeping the first one extended.
Press it back up.
Continue alternating arms.
Requires more core stability.
Repeat.
description: Pressing dumbbells one arm at a time while the other remains extended, challenging stability.

name: Single-Arm Dumbbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie on a flat or incline bench holding one dumbbell.
Position the dumbbell above your chest, arm extended.
Engage your core strongly to prevent rotation.
Lower the dumbbell towards your chest under control.
Press the dumbbell back up.
Focus on maintaining stability and preventing your torso from twisting.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing a dumbbell bench press with only one arm, significantly challenging core and anti-rotational strength.

name: Dumbbell Flyes (Flat)
instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding dumbbells.
Start with dumbbells pressed above your chest, palms facing each other, elbows slightly bent.
Maintain the slight bend in your elbows throughout.
Slowly lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc.
Feel a stretch across your chest.
Lower until dumbbells are about level with your chest.
Reverse the motion, bringing the dumbbells back together over your chest using your pectoral muscles (imagine hugging a tree).
Avoid clanging dumbbells at the top.
Repeat.
description: An isolation exercise for the chest using dumbbells, involving opening and closing the arms in a wide arc.

name: Dumbbell Flyes (Incline)
instructions: Lie on an incline bench (30-45 degrees) holding dumbbells.
Perform the flye motion as described for flat bench flyes.
Press dumbbells up, palms facing each other, elbows slightly bent.
Lower out to the sides in an arc.
Bring dumbbells back together over your upper chest.
Focus on the upper chest stretch and contraction.
Repeat.
description: Dumbbell flyes performed on an incline bench to target the upper portion of the chest.

name: Dumbbell Flyes (Decline)
instructions: Lie on a decline bench, securing legs.
Hold dumbbells and perform the flye motion.
Press dumbbells up over lower chest, palms facing, elbows slightly bent.
Lower out to the sides in an arc.
Bring dumbbells back together over lower chest.
Focus on the lower chest.
Repeat.
description: Dumbbell flyes performed on a decline bench to emphasize the lower portion of the chest.

name: Cable Flyes (High-to-Low)
instructions: Set cable pulleys to a high position.
Grab handles, step forward into a staggered stance.
Lean forward slightly.
Start with arms extended up and out to the sides.
Keeping elbows slightly bent, bring the handles down and together in front of your lower chest/waist.
Squeeze chest muscles.
Slowly return arms to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A cable fly variation starting high and pulling down, targeting the lower chest fibers.

name: Cable Flyes (Mid-Chest)
instructions: Set cable pulleys at chest height.
Grab handles, step forward.
Start with arms extended out to the sides, elbows slightly bent.
Bring the handles together directly in front of your mid-chest.
Squeeze pectoral muscles.
Slowly return arms to the starting position, feeling a stretch.
Repeat.
description: A cable fly variation performed with pulleys at chest level, targeting the mid-portion of the chest.

name: Cable Flyes (Low-to-High)
instructions: Set cable pulleys to a low position.
Grab handles, step forward slightly.
Start with arms down and slightly out to the sides.
Keeping elbows slightly bent, bring the handles up and together in front of your upper chest/eye level.
Squeeze upper chest muscles.
Slowly return arms to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A cable fly variation starting low and pulling up, targeting the upper chest fibers.

name: Pec Deck Machine Fly
instructions: Sit in the Pec Deck machine, back flat against the pad.
Place forearms against the pads (if applicable) or grip the handles.
Adjust seat height so handles/pads align with mid-chest.
Starting with arms open, squeeze handles/pads together in front of your chest by contracting pectoral muscles.
Pause at peak contraction.
Slowly return to the starting position, feeling a stretch.
Repeat.
description: A machine-based chest isolation exercise mimicking the flye motion.

name: Chest Press Machine
instructions: Sit in the chest press machine, back flat against the pad.
Adjust seat height so handles are at mid-chest level.
Grip the handles with desired grip width.
Press the handles forward by extending your elbows and contracting your chest.
Do not lock out elbows completely.
Slowly return the handles to the starting position under control.
Repeat.
description: A machine-based exercise simulating a bench press movement, providing stability.

name: Dumbbell Pullover (Chest Focus)
instructions: Lie perpendicular across a flat bench with only your upper back supported.
Feet flat on the floor, hips low.
Hold a single dumbbell with both hands (diamond grip or cupping the end) above your chest.
Keeping elbows slightly bent, lower the dumbbell backward over your head in an arc.
Lower until you feel a good stretch in your chest and lats.
To focus on chest: Initiate the return by pulling with your chest muscles, bringing the dumbbell back over your chest.
Keep hips low throughout.
Repeat.
description: An exercise involving lowering a dumbbell behind the head while lying across a bench, potentially targeting chest or lats depending on focus.

name: Barbell Overhead Press (Strict)
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart.
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width, resting it on your upper chest/front shoulders (front rack position).
Keep core braced, glutes tight.
Press the barbell straight overhead, fully extending elbows.
Push head slightly forward 'through the window' at the top so the bar is aligned over your spine.
Lower the barbell under control back to the starting position.
Use only shoulder and arm strength; no leg drive.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental shoulder exercise pressing a barbell strictly overhead without leg assistance.

name: Barbell Push Press
instructions: Start with the barbell in the front rack position, feet hip-width apart.
Perform a shallow dip by bending knees and hips slightly.
Immediately drive explosively upwards with your legs, transferring momentum to the barbell.
As the bar moves upwards, press forcefully with your arms to lock it out overhead.
Lower the bar under control back to the shoulders.
Reset and repeat the dip-drive-press sequence.
description: An overhead press variation using leg drive (dip and drive) to help initiate the movement, allowing heavier weight.

name: Barbell Push Jerk / Split Jerk
instructions: Start with the barbell in the front rack position.
Perform a dip similar to the push press.
Drive explosively upwards with legs.
As the bar travels up, quickly drop *under* the bar by either:
Push Jerk: Re-bending knees into a partial squat.
Split Jerk: Splitting legs into a lunge stance (one forward, one back).
Catch the bar overhead with locked arms in the lowered stance.
Recover by standing up straight (push jerk) or bringing feet back together (split jerk).
Lower bar under control.
Repeat.
description: Olympic weightlifting movements involving driving a barbell overhead and dropping underneath it to catch in a stable position.

name: Seated Barbell Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit on a bench with back support.
Take the barbell from a rack or have it handed to you, resting it on upper chest/shoulders.
Grip slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Keep back supported, core braced.
Press the barbell straight overhead.
Lower under control back to the starting position.
The seated position eliminates leg drive and requires strict pressing strength.
Repeat.
description: Performing a barbell overhead press while seated, isolating the shoulders and triceps.

name: Dumbbell Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit on a bench with back support or stand.
Hold dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing forward.
Keep core braced.
Press the dumbbells straight overhead, bringing them slightly closer together at the top.
Lower the dumbbells under control back to shoulder height.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental shoulder exercise using dumbbells, performed seated or standing.

name: Neutral Grip Dumbbell Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit or stand holding dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing each other (neutral grip).
Press the dumbbells straight overhead.
Keep palms facing each other throughout the movement.
Lower under control back to shoulder height.
May be easier on the shoulder joint for some.
Repeat.
description: A dumbbell shoulder press variation with palms facing each other, potentially reducing shoulder impingement risk.

name: Alternating Dumbbell Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit or stand holding dumbbells at shoulder height.
Press one dumbbell overhead while keeping the other stable at shoulder height.
Lower the first dumbbell back down.
Press the second dumbbell overhead while keeping the first one stable.
Lower the second dumbbell.
Continue alternating arms.
Increases time under tension and core demand.
Repeat.
description: Pressing dumbbells overhead one arm at a time, increasing stability challenge.

name: Single-Arm Dumbbell Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit or stand holding one dumbbell at shoulder height.
Brace your core tightly to resist leaning.
Press the dumbbell straight overhead.
Lower under control back to shoulder height.
Focus on maintaining an upright and stable torso.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing a dumbbell shoulder press with only one arm, significantly challenging core stability.

name: Arnold Press
instructions: Sit on a bench with back support.
Hold dumbbells in front of your shoulders, palms facing your body, elbows bent.
Begin pressing the dumbbells overhead.
As you press up, rotate your wrists so that your palms face forward at the top of the movement.
Fully extend arms overhead.
Reverse the motion as you lower the dumbbells, rotating palms back towards your body at the bottom.
Repeat.
description: A dumbbell shoulder press variation involving rotation during the press, targeting all heads of the deltoid.

name: Machine Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit in the shoulder press machine, back flat against the pad.
Adjust seat height so handles start near shoulder level.
Grip the handles (usually pronated or neutral grip options).
Press the handles straight overhead, extending elbows.
Lower the handles back down under control.
Provides stability compared to free weights.
Repeat.
description: Performing an overhead press using a dedicated machine for stability and guided movement.

name: Smith Machine Shoulder Press
instructions: Position a bench (usually upright or slightly inclined) under the Smith machine bar.
Sit down and grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Position yourself so the bar path allows pressing overhead.
Unlatch the bar.
Lower the bar towards your upper chest/shoulders.
Press the bar straight up along the machine's path.
Rerack safely.
Repeat.
description: Performing an overhead press using the guided path of a Smith machine.

name: Landmine Press
instructions: Place one end of a barbell into a landmine attachment or securely in a corner.
Load the other end with weight.
Stand facing the weighted end (or kneel on one knee).
Grip the end of the barbell sleeve with one or both hands at chest/shoulder height.
Press the barbell upwards and forwards along its natural arc.
Keep core braced.
Lower under control back to the starting position.
Can be done unilaterally or bilaterally.
Repeat.
description: Pressing the end of a barbell anchored in a landmine attachment, targeting the shoulders and upper chest.

name: Lateral Raise
instructions: Stand or sit tall, holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing your body.
Keep a slight bend in your elbows.
Raise the dumbbells straight out to your sides in a wide arc.
Lead with your elbows slightly, keeping thumbs pointing slightly down ('pouring water' cue, use with caution).
Raise until arms are parallel to the floor or slightly below.
Avoid swinging or using momentum.
Lower the dumbbells slowly back to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: An isolation exercise targeting the side (lateral) head of the deltoid muscle by raising arms out to the sides.

name: Leaning Lateral Raise
instructions: Stand sideways next to a sturdy pole or rack, holding onto it with one hand.
Lean your body away from the support.
Hold a dumbbell in the free hand, letting it hang down.
Keeping a slight bend in the elbow, raise the dumbbell out to the side in an arc.
The lean changes the resistance curve, making the bottom part harder.
Lower slowly under control.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A lateral raise variation performed while leaning, altering the resistance profile to emphasize the initial part of the lift.

name: Cable Lateral Raise
instructions: Set a cable pulley to the lowest position.
Attach a handle.
Stand sideways to the machine, grabbing the handle with the hand furthest away (cable crosses in front of body).
Keep a slight bend in the elbow.
Raise your arm out to the side in an arc, leading slightly with the elbow.
Raise until arm is parallel to the floor.
Lower slowly under control.
Cable provides constant tension.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing lateral raises using a cable machine for constant tension throughout the movement.

name: Machine Lateral Raise
instructions: Sit in the lateral raise machine, adjusting seat height.
Place the outside of your upper arms against the pads.
Grip handles if available.
Raise your arms outwards and upwards by pushing against the pads.
Focus on using your side deltoids.
Lift until pads are roughly shoulder height.
Lower slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: Using a dedicated machine to isolate the lateral deltoids through an abduction movement.

name: Front Raise (Dumbbell)
instructions: Stand or sit holding dumbbells in front of your thighs, palms facing your body.
Keep elbows slightly bent.
Raise one dumbbell straight forward and upwards until it reaches shoulder height.
Avoid swinging or leaning back.
Lower the dumbbell slowly under control.
Either alternate arms or raise both simultaneously.
Repeat.
description: An isolation exercise targeting the front (anterior) head of the deltoid by raising arms straight forward.

name: Front Raise (Plate)
instructions: Stand holding a weight plate with both hands (grip sides).
Hold the plate down in front of your thighs.
Keeping arms mostly straight (slight elbow bend), raise the plate forward and upward.
Lift until the plate is at shoulder height or slightly above.
Avoid momentum.
Lower the plate slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: Performing front raises using a weight plate gripped with both hands.

name: Front Raise (Cable)
instructions: Set a cable pulley to the lowest position.
Attach a handle or rope.
Stand facing away from the machine, grabbing the attachment (handle between legs or rope).
Keeping arm(s) straight (slight elbow bend), raise the attachment forward and upward.
Lift to shoulder height.
Lower slowly under control.
Can be done one arm or two arms.
Repeat.
description: Using a cable machine for front raises, providing constant tension.

name: Barbell Front Raise
instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart.
Hold the bar in front of your thighs.
Keeping arms straight (slight elbow bend), raise the barbell forward and upward.
Lift until the bar is at shoulder height.
Avoid using momentum or excessive leaning.
Lower the barbell slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: Performing front raises using a barbell, often requiring more control than dumbbells.

name: Rear Delt Fly (Dumbbell)
instructions: Either sit on the edge of a bench leaning forward, or stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hinging at the hips with a flat back (torso close to parallel with floor).
Hold dumbbells with palms facing each other, arms hanging straight down.
Maintain a slight bend in your elbows.
Keeping torso stationary, raise the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc.
Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together and using your rear deltoids.
Raise until arms are roughly parallel to the floor.
Lower slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: An exercise targeting the rear (posterior) deltoids by opening the arms horizontally while bent over.

name: Rear Delt Fly (Cable)
instructions: Set two cable pulleys at shoulder height or slightly lower.
Stand in the center.
Grab the left handle with your right hand, and the right handle with your left hand (cables crossed).
Step back slightly for tension.
Keep arms mostly straight, slight elbow bend.
Pull the handles outwards and slightly backwards in a wide arc, keeping arms at shoulder height.
Focus on squeezing rear deltoids and upper back.
Return slowly to the starting position.
Can also be done bent over with low pulleys.
Repeat.
description: Using cables to perform a rear delt fly, providing constant tension.

name: Reverse Pec Deck Machine
instructions: Adjust the Pec Deck machine handles/arms to the rearmost starting position.
Sit facing the machine, chest against the pad.
Grip the handles with palms facing each other or down.
Keeping arms mostly straight (slight elbow bend), push the handles/pads outwards and backwards.
Focus on squeezing your rear deltoids and upper back.
Move through a comfortable range of motion.
Return slowly to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: Using a Pec Deck machine in reverse to isolate the posterior deltoids and upper back muscles.

name: Face Pull (Cable)
instructions: Set a cable pulley at chest or head height.
Attach a rope handle.
Grip the rope with palms facing each other or down.
Step back to create tension.
Pull the rope towards your face, aiming the handles towards your ears.
Simultaneously drive your elbows back and high, and externally rotate your shoulders (thumbs point back).
Squeeze your upper back and rear deltoids at the end.
Return slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: A key exercise for shoulder health and upper back development, targeting rear deltoids and external rotators.

name: Band Face Pull
instructions: Anchor a resistance band at chest or head height.
Grip the band with both hands.
Step back for tension.
Pull the band towards your face, driving elbows back and high.
Focus on external rotation and squeezing upper back.
Return slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: Performing face pulls using a resistance band instead of a cable.

name: High Row
instructions: Set a cable pulley at chest height (or use dumbbells bent over).
Use a wide grip bar or rope.
Sit or stand facing the pulley.
Pull the attachment towards your upper chest/collarbone, driving your elbows high and out to the sides.
Keep torso stable.
Squeeze your upper back and rear deltoids.
Return slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: A rowing variation pulling towards the upper chest with elbows high, targeting the upper back and rear deltoids.

name: Barbell Upright Row
instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an overhand grip, hands closer than shoulder-width.
Let the bar hang in front of your thighs.
Pull the barbell straight up towards your chin, leading with your elbows.
Keep the bar close to your body.
Elbows should end up higher than wrists.
Lower the bar slowly under control.
Use caution: This exercise can cause shoulder impingement for some individuals. Avoid if painful.
Repeat.
description: Pulling a barbell vertically towards the chin, targeting traps and deltoids. Use caution due to potential shoulder impingement risk.

name: Dumbbell Upright Row
instructions: Stand holding dumbbells in front of your thighs, palms facing body.
Pull the dumbbells straight up towards your shoulders, leading with elbows.
Keep dumbbells close to body.
Elbows should be higher than wrists at the top.
Lower slowly under control.
May allow a more natural wrist position than barbell version.
Repeat.
description: Performing upright rows with dumbbells, potentially allowing a more comfortable wrist and shoulder position.

name: Cable Upright Row
instructions: Set a cable pulley to the lowest position.
Attach a straight bar or rope.
Stand facing the machine, grip the attachment.
Pull the attachment straight up towards your chin, leading with elbows.
Keep it close to your body.
Lower slowly under control.
Repeat.
description: Using a cable machine to perform upright rows.

name: Lu Raises
instructions: Stand holding light dumbbells at your sides, palms facing body.
Simultaneously perform a lateral raise (arms out to sides) and a front raise (arms forward).
Continue the motion until dumbbells meet overhead or arms are fully extended overhead.
Keep elbows slightly bent.
Lower slowly along the same path.
Combines lateral and front raise patterns into one fluid movement.
Repeat.
description: A combination exercise moving dumbbells from the sides through a lateral and front raise path to overhead.

name: Dips (Chest Focus)
instructions: Support yourself on parallel bars, arms straight.
Lean your torso forward significantly (around 30-45 degrees).
Lower your body by bending your elbows, allowing them to flare out slightly.
Descend until you feel a good stretch in your chest or shoulders are below elbows.
Push back up to the starting position, focusing on chest contraction.
Repeat.
description: Performing dips with a forward lean to emphasize the pectoral muscles.

name: Dips (Triceps Focus)
instructions: Support yourself on parallel bars, arms straight.
Keep your torso as upright as possible.
Lower your body by bending your elbows, keeping them tucked closer to your sides.
Descend until elbows reach about 90 degrees.
Push back up forcefully, focusing on triceps extension.
Repeat.
description: Performing dips with an upright torso to emphasize the triceps muscles.

name: Bench Dips
instructions: Sit on the edge of a bench, hands gripping the edge next to your hips, fingers pointing forward.
Place your feet flat on the floor with knees bent (easier) or extend legs straight with heels on floor/another bench (harder).
Lift your hips off the bench and move slightly forward.
Lower your body by bending your elbows straight back until they reach about 90 degrees.
Keep your back close to the bench.
Push back up through your palms, extending your triceps.
Repeat.
description: A dip variation performed with hands on a bench and feet on the floor or another bench.

name: Ring Dips
instructions: Support yourself on gymnastic rings, arms straight, rings close to body.
Engage core, keep body stable.
Lower down by bending elbows (keep them relatively tucked).
Control the descent, managing the instability of the rings.
Lower to desired depth (e.g., shoulders below elbows).
Press back up forcefully to the starting support position.
Requires significant stability and strength.
Repeat.
description: Performing dips on unstable gymnastic rings, significantly increasing the stability demand.

name: Machine Dips
instructions: Sit in the dip machine, adjusting seat height.
Grip the handles (palms facing in or down depending on machine).
Keep chest up, shoulders down.
Press the handles downwards by extending your elbows.
Focus on triceps contraction.
Slowly allow handles to return to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: Using a dedicated machine to mimic the dip movement, providing stability and guided resistance.

name: Triceps Pushdown (Straight Bar)
instructions: Attach a straight bar to a high cable pulley.
Stand facing the machine, grab the bar with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart or closer.
Keep elbows tucked close to your sides, upper arms stationary.
Start with elbows bent at about 90 degrees.
Push the bar straight down by extending your elbows.
Contract triceps fully at the bottom.
Slowly return the bar to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: A fundamental cable exercise isolating the triceps using a straight bar attachment.

name: Triceps Pushdown (V-Bar)
instructions: Attach a V-bar to a high cable pulley.
Grab the V-bar with palms facing each other.
Stand facing the machine, elbows tucked in.
Push the bar down by extending elbows, keeping upper arms still.
Squeeze triceps at the bottom.
Slowly return to the start.
Repeat.
description: A triceps pushdown variation using a V-bar attachment, often allowing a comfortable wrist position.

name: Triceps Pushdown (Rope)
instructions: Attach a rope handle to a high cable pulley.
Grab the rope ends with a neutral grip (palms facing each other).
Stand facing the machine, elbows tucked in.
Push down by extending elbows.
At the bottom, slightly separate the rope ends outwards to intensify the contraction.
Squeeze triceps.
Slowly return to the start.
Repeat.
description: A popular triceps pushdown variation using a rope attachment, allowing for wrist rotation and potentially greater contraction.

name: Single Arm Triceps Pushdown
instructions: Attach a single handle (or use end of rope) to a high cable pulley.
Stand facing the machine, grab the handle with one hand (overhand or neutral grip).
Keep elbow tucked to your side, upper arm stationary.
Push the handle down by extending your elbow.
Squeeze triceps.
Return slowly.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing triceps pushdowns one arm at a time for unilateral focus.

name: Reverse Grip Triceps Pushdown
instructions: Attach a straight bar or EZ bar to a high cable pulley.
Grab the bar with an underhand (reverse) grip, hands shoulder-width apart.
Stand facing the machine, elbows tucked in.
Push the bar down by extending elbows.
Focus on triceps contraction (may feel different due to grip).
Return slowly.
Repeat.
description: A triceps pushdown variation using an underhand grip, targeting the medial head of the triceps differently.

name: Overhead Triceps Extension (Dumbbell)
instructions: Sit or stand tall.
Hold a single dumbbell with both hands cupped under the top end, or hold one dumbbell in each hand.
Extend the dumbbell(s) straight overhead.
Keeping upper arms stationary and close to your head, lower the dumbbell(s) behind your head by bending your elbows.
Lower until you feel a stretch in your triceps.
Extend your elbows to push the dumbbell(s) back to the starting overhead position.
Squeeze triceps at the top.
Repeat.
description: Extending dumbbell(s) overhead to isolate the triceps, particularly the long head.

name: Overhead Triceps Extension (Cable)
instructions: Attach a rope or bar to a low cable pulley.
Stand facing away from the machine.
Grab the attachment and extend it overhead.
Keep upper arms stationary near your head.
Lower the attachment behind your head by bending elbows.
Extend elbows fully to push the attachment back up.
Squeeze triceps.
Repeat.
description: Performing overhead triceps extensions using a cable for constant tension.

name: Skullcrusher (Barbell)
instructions: Lie flat or on a decline bench.
Hold a barbell (straight or EZ bar) with a narrow overhand grip, arms extended perpendicular to the floor.
Keeping upper arms stationary, lower the barbell towards your forehead by bending only at the elbows.
Lower under control.
Extend your elbows to push the bar back to the starting position.
Focus on triceps contraction.
Repeat.
description: A classic triceps isolation exercise involving lowering a barbell towards the forehead while lying down.

name: Skullcrusher (Dumbbell)
instructions: Lie flat or on a decline bench holding dumbbells.
Extend arms perpendicular to the floor, palms facing each other (neutral grip) or forward (pronated).
Keeping upper arms stationary, lower the dumbbells towards the sides of your head by bending elbows.
Extend elbows to push dumbbells back to the starting position.
Repeat.
description: Performing skullcrushers using dumbbells, allowing for different grip variations.

name: JM Press
instructions: Lie flat on a bench holding a barbell with a close grip (similar to close-grip bench press).
Lower the bar in a path somewhere between a close-grip bench and a skullcrusher - towards the upper chest/neck area.
Elbows should point towards your feet more than a standard skullcrusher.
Allow elbows to drop down slightly.
Press back up focusing on triceps.
Hybrid movement requiring specific technique.
Repeat.
description: A hybrid pressing/extension movement targeting the triceps, often used by powerlifters.

name: Dumbbell Tricep Kickback
instructions: Stand hinged at the hips with a flat back, torso close to parallel with floor. Support upper body with one hand on a bench or knee.
Hold a dumbbell in the other hand, upper arm parallel to the floor, elbow bent at 90 degrees.
Keeping upper arm stationary, extend your elbow to push the dumbbell straight back.
Squeeze the triceps at full extension.
Slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position.
Avoid swinging.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: A triceps isolation exercise performed bent-over, extending the elbow backward against dumbbell resistance.

name: Cable Tricep Kickback
instructions: Set a cable pulley to a low position.
Attach a handle.
Stand hinged at the hips, facing the machine (or sideways).
Grab handle, position upper arm parallel to floor (or tucked to side), elbow bent.
Keeping upper arm still, extend elbow straight back against cable resistance.
Squeeze triceps.
Return slowly.
Complete reps on one side before switching.
Repeat.
description: Performing triceps kickbacks using a cable machine for constant tension.

name: Close-Grip Push-Up
instructions: Start in a high plank position with hands closer than shoulder-width (on floor or elevated surface like bench/bar).
Keep body straight, core engaged.
Lower chest towards hands/surface, keeping elbows tucked close to sides.
Push back up, focusing on triceps extension.
Elevation makes it easier.
Repeat.
description: A push-up variation with narrow hand placement to emphasize triceps, performed on floor or elevated surface.

name: Tate Press
instructions: Lie flat or on an incline bench holding dumbbells.
Start with arms extended over chest, palms facing feet.
Keeping upper arms relatively stationary, lower the dumbbells towards your chest by bending your elbows, allowing elbows to point outwards.
The dumbbells will move towards the center of your chest.
Extend elbows to press the dumbbells back up, rotating palms slightly.
Focus on triceps.
Repeat.
description: A dumbbell triceps exercise involving lowering the weights towards the chest with elbows flared.

name: Bodyweight Triceps Extension
instructions: Set up a low bar, Smith machine bar, or suspension trainer handles.
